summary: Paul Merson criticized Andros Townsend's inclusion in the England team, but later admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored against Italy. However, Merson restarted their public row by mocking the Tottenham midfielder on Twitter for playing only seven minutes in a subsequent club game.

Chelsea has made a formal summer offer for 22-year-old FC Tokyo and Japan forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane. A potential £4 million deal has been suggested, and if completed, Muto would be loaned to Vitesse Arnhem next season. Muto has not yet decided on the move but called the offer an honour. The club president claims Chelsea's interest is not linked to their £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale study published in the journal Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The research on over 12,000 children indicated that repeated antibiotic prescriptions before age two also increased the odds of being overweight, with boys being particularly prone to the effect. While the study did not prove causation, researchers hypothesize that antibiotics may alter gut bacteria, freeing up more calories for the body or increasing appetite. The findings suggest that early antibiotic exposure could be a factor in the childhood obesity epidemic and highlight the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident, recorded on camera, saw the guard drop his rifle and knock his bearskin, leaving him visibly embarrassed. The fall is thought to have been caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots.

A&E Networks are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots" to simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History in 2016. The contemporary adaptation, which will draw more from Alex Haley's novel, retells the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African man sold into slavery, and his descendants. LeVar Burton, the original star of "Roots," will serve as a co-executive producer, and producers will consult historians for authenticity to introduce the story of Kunta Kinte's indomitable spirit to a new generation of viewers.

Former royal footman Christopher Lawler claims palace aides tried to force him into an orgy at Clarence House in 1978. He alleges he was pinned to a chair and groped on his first day, threatened to keep quiet, and resigned immediately. After being twice rebuffed by the Palace last year, his complaint was eventually passed to the police, who are now investigating. A retired royal aide has denied any involvement.

Oregon couple Jesse and Melissa Meek announced they are expecting a child by creating a rap video parody set to the theme from 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their life, their decision to have a baby, and the positive pregnancy test, culminating in a sonogram reveal. The Meeks, who made the video to inform distant relatives, were surprised by its viral success and are considering another video to announce the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, which has faded from its original slate blue-gray, was part of a collection belonging to James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios department head who purchased the dress for $20 in the 1960s when it was about to be discarded. The dress was worn in several key scenes, and the auction also featured other items from the film, including a hat worn by Leigh that sold for $52,500 and a suit worn by Clark Gable that fetched $55,000.

A two-year-old boy fell approximately 10 to 12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents allegedly dangled him over a railing. The boy was rescued by his parents and suffered only minor bumps, bruises, and an injured leg; he was not attacked by the cheetahs, which did not approach him. Based on eyewitness accounts, zoo officials plan to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit has been closed.

A decommissioned speed camera in Birmingham was repositioned to aim at a house's front door. The camera, along with all others in the West Midlands, had been switched off since 2013 due to obsolete technology. Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation, will investigate, and may remove the camera, confirming it will not be part of a new pilot for digital cameras.

Six-time Olympic gold medallist Usain Bolt will compete for the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association announced his participation, and Bolt confirmed he is fit, healthy, and ready to run, stating he aims to make his country proud.

Barcelona teammates Neymar and Dani Alves attended a basketball El Clasico between their club and Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Separately, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile. Before the international break, Barcelona's football team had moved four points clear at the top of La Liga after winning their El Clasico match.

Italy is experiencing a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with the coast guard rescuing 8,480 people over a four-day period. A report from Save the Children fears 400 migrants are missing after a boat capsized off Libya, but the Italian coast guard cannot confirm the incident after finding no evidence. According to the International Organization for Migration, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, and at least 480 have died while attempting the crossing, often due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by smugglers. Most migrants use Libya as a transit country and come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria.

Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sánchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, though he does not know the exact reason for the decision. Since his £32 million transfer, Sánchez has made an immediate impact, scoring 19 goals. Wenger speculated that Liverpool's interest in Sánchez might have been leverage in the Luis Suárez transfer negotiations. The Arsenal manager praised Sánchez's work-rate and fighting spirit, and also dismissed speculation linking him with a move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, Sir Bradley Wiggins, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. He aims to surpass the current mark of 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis. The attempt, which follows his departure from Team Sky, will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with tickets available from April 19.

World No. 1 Serena Williams struggled to beat Sara Errani in a Fed Cup singles match, a win she described as an "eye-opener" that showed she was not prepared for the claycourt season. Despite her victory, the US team lost the tie 3-2 after a doubles defeat, resulting in their relegation to World Group II. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez said the team must work harder to return to the World Group.

River Plate are keen to re-sign their former striker, Radamel Falcao, a deal the club's vice president, Matias Patanian, describes as complicated while stating "the doors are open." Falcao, a 29-year-old Colombian, has struggled during his season-long loan at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals, and his future is uncertain as he may return to parent club Monaco. He previously played for River Plate for eight years, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances, and recently tied Colombia's all-time goalscoring record despite his club struggles.

19-year-old pop star and 2012 X Factor finalist Ella Henderson has been announced as the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The international campaign includes a TV advertisement featuring the singer's single, "Mirror Man."

A billboard in Kenosha, Wisconsin, featuring Officer Pablo Torres has caused shock for the family and friends of Aaron Siler, a man fatally shot by Torres. Paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, the billboard thanks the community for its support. Siler's family and friends call the billboard "disrespectful" and want it taken down, while the police association claims it was not intended to cause offense. Siler was shot on March 14 after a pursuit; he was wanted on a felony warrant and had armed himself with a weapon. The investigation into his death is ongoing, and Officer Torres is on leave. Ten days before the Siler shooting, Torres also shot and wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with knives; that shooting was investigated and deemed justified by the District Attorney.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in a clash with militants from the group Jaish al Adal near the Pakistan border. Iranian forces killed three of the attackers, who had crossed into Iran from Pakistan. Iran has asked Pakistani authorities to apprehend the surviving militants, while Pakistan has condemned the attack and promised to investigate and bring the perpetrators to justice if they entered Pakistani territory. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni militant group, has claimed responsibility for previous similar attacks.

Japanese Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated in parliament that the country's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO. He was responding to a question from lawmaker and former wrestler Antonio Inoki, who asked if jets were ever scrambled to meet alien threats. Nakatani explained that while jets are sometimes scrambled for unidentified objects, they have only found birds or other terrestrial objects. The passage notes this is not the first time Japanese politicians have discussed the topic, as a similar debate occurred in 2007.

A 35-year-old passenger named Jin Pai was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after squatting on a toilet rim in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. The toilet shattered because he was worried the seat was unclean. He received dozens of stitches and later changed his story to police, possibly to avoid compensation, after initially confessing to friends. Authorities deemed the incident an accident and reminded the public that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera in her bathroom, which police traced to him. He faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation revealed Rebbie had sexually abused the girl from ages 9 to 13 and had filmed her and other victims using the bathroom over several years. He admitted to buying the camera specifically to record the girl and to filming other juveniles. Rebbie is being held on $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a photo series, roughly translated as "Daughter and Salary Man," which features sharply dressed fathers leaping into the air next to their casually dressed, often po-faced or smiling daughters. The images, taken at various Japanese landmarks, are intended to allow serious fathers to express a fun side. The series has gained significant online interest for its curious nature, though little else is known about its origin.

Following the dismissal of England's managing director Paul Downton, who controversially axed Kevin Pietersen in 2014, focus has shifted to the county championship season where Pietersen is playing for Surrey. Pietersen is attempting to force his way back into the England Test set-up for the upcoming Ashes. During a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval, Pietersen appeared both in deep thought and jovial, joking with photographers and teammates.

Relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. After being initially fired for a poor run, he was reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone before being dismissed again following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. The result left Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points from safety, and Ze Maria will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes the Colombian regrets his loan move to Manchester United. Dirar states that despite Falcao being unhappy in France, he would have been better off staying at Monaco where he could have played in the Champions League. Falcao's season at United was unsuccessful; he scored only four goals and failed to reach his pre-injury form, making it unlikely that the club will pay the £46 million to sign him permanently.

New Zealand police are seeking a 'very tall' man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday around 12:30 pm. The offender, wearing a 'distinctive' cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, stole the till and approximately $1500 after demanding cash from the owner's daughter. Police report no weapons were used and the robber remains at large. They are asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old Texas math teacher, was arrested twice for alleged inappropriate relationships with underage students. She was first arrested in March for kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts. After rumors surfaced at her school following the first arrest, a second 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested a second time, released on a $50,000 bail, and has been suspended by the school district, remaining on administrative leave.

A video of a large crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times online. The dog, which belonged to a local bike shop owner, was reportedly curious at the water's edge before the attack. A tourist witness, Tim Weston, stated the crocodile held the dog for hours. The video, which caused horrified reactions on social media, highlights the common presence of American crocodiles in the resort area, which is built in their natural mangrove habitat.

Following a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, Hull City are battling relegation, sitting just two points above the drop zone. Manager Steve Bruce is adamant he can keep Hull in the Premier League, blaming their struggles on long-term injuries to key players and believing that eight or nine wins might be enough for survival. Despite difficult upcoming fixtures against top teams, Bruce remains convinced his side will stay up. The win moved Southampton to fifth in the table, but manager Ronald Koeman will address a disciplinary issue after Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty that was not his.

Teacher Ian Guffick was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils at Mitton Manor Primary School to change their SATs exam answers after the test had finished, and also altered some answers himself. His actions led to the entire school's SATs results being annulled by the Department for Education. Guffick, who claimed he was only making answers more legible, admitted the allegations amounted to unacceptable professional conduct and showed remorse.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard has struggled for playing time since joining in 2010 and is now the third-choice keeper. Despite his professional difficulties, his personal life is successful; he is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, with whom he has a son, and the couple wed in Mauritius last year.

The 13 glowing blue letters from the former Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite an estimate of $300,000 to $600,000. The 10-foot-tall letters, which were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008, are owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson. Jackson, who purchased the signage after the stadium's final game and called the buy "on a lark," wanted a new generation to own the icon. No bids were placed for the letters, though a Sotheby's employee offered $260,000 to start the bidding. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car sold at the same auction for $112,500, well above its $20,000 to $30,000 estimate.

Following off-field incidents involving Raheem Sterling and nitrous oxide, and Sterling and Jordon Ibe with shisha pipes, Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reminded the players of their professional responsibilities. After speaking with them, Rodgers decided not to discipline either and wants to move on from the matter. The team is preparing for an FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, where Sterling will lead the attack due to Daniel Sturridge's injury and Steven Gerrard is available after a suspension.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil returned to London from international duty with Germany and is preparing for the team's match against Liverpool. After missing Arsenal's previous game due to illness, he is expected to start. Ozil has been in good form since returning from injury in January, with four assists and three goals, and he states he is adjusting well to the demanding English football schedule, claiming he fits in "perfectly" because he prefers playing many matches.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu insists the club will not replace manager Luis Enrique and is "very happy" with his performance. Despite speculation, Bartomeu is impressed with Enrique, who took charge last summer and has the team contending for three trophies, as demonstrated by a recent victory over Valencia.

Liverpool's 24-year-old vice-captain, Jordan Henderson, has agreed to a new long-term contract worth around £100,000-a-week that will run until 2020. Following an excellent season, he is considered a potential successor to captain Steven Gerrard. Henderson is the third key player to sign a contract extension under manager Brendan Rodgers, after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho.

Despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him, full-back Filipe Luis insists he is happy at Chelsea and intends to stay until his contract ends. Although he has struggled to secure a regular starting position, his and manager Jose Mourinho's focus is on winning the Premier League title with nine difficult games remaining.

Wasps player Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North overturned on appeal. The initial suspension followed a red card for a knee-to-head collision during a match on March 27, which an initial panel deemed 'reckless'. After an outcry and a successful appeal by Wasps, the ban and red card were rescinded. An appeal panel concluded the incident was accidental and involved no foul play. Hughes missed one match awaiting the appeal and is now free to play, while North was left unconscious and advised to take a month off for his concussion symptoms.

Fiery red sunsets in Washington and the Pacific Northwest were caused by smoke from Siberian wildfires. The fires started on April 14 when farmers burning grass lost control due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. Atmospheric winds carried the smoke across the Pacific, where particles filtered out shorter-wavelength colors from the sunlight, allowing intense red and orange hues to dominate, especially at sunset. The sunsets will lose their reddish color as the smoke dissipates and air quality improves.

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen. The car was later found and returned with custom modifications, including red spray-painted rims and detailing. Schoenig reacted with amusement, posting on Facebook that the thieves had "pimped out" her vehicle. Although the car needs professional cleaning to remove smoke and marijuana odors, she is honoring the man who located it, Mick Sexton, by creating a special smoothie at her restaurant.

Manchester City players will lose £500,000 each in bonuses, totaling around £12 million for the squad, if they fail to qualify for the Champions League. These incentivised contracts are designed to comply with financial fair play rules. After a recent loss to Manchester United, the team is in fourth place, and their qualification hopes are uncertain following a poor run of form. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team had let their season disintegrate, and failure to secure a top-four finish could also hinder their attempts to sign world-class players.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' held at Altrincham's Moss Lane stadium, a venue chosen to give the players a senior-level experience. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick. The victory leaves United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has now lost both matches in their play-off series.

During a 1-1 draw with Italy, England goalkeeper Joe Hart earned his 50th cap and praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon, who won his 147th. Hart labelled Buffon a "legend of the game" and an "inspiration," stating he is still learning from the 37-year-old. The Manchester City goalkeeper expressed pride in his own milestone and his ambition to continue earning more caps for his country.

Mexican restaurant Chipotle is partnering with the Postmates app to offer food delivery in 67 cities for online and mobile orders. The service will include a nine percent Chipotle service charge in addition to Postmates delivery fees starting at $5. This move is part of a larger trend, with other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, and Burger King also entering the food delivery market.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Bill and Denise Richard, are pleading with the Justice Department to remove the death penalty for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In a newspaper column, they argue that a life sentence without parole and a waiver of all appeals would bring their family closure and spare them from years of reliving the trauma, which killed their 8-year-old son and severely injured their daughter. They believe the prolonged appeals process of a death penalty case would only prolong their anguish.

A Boeing 747 has been converted into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire at a cost of £400 million over a three-year period. The custom-built jet, which normally carries 600 passengers, is designed for one owner and dozens of guests. Its interior, resembling a luxury hotel, includes multiple bedrooms, multiple lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, and a conference room.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket with a Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station, but its attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge failed when it tipped over after landing too hard. The company's goal is to land and reuse rockets to reduce space access costs by as much as a hundredfold. The Dragon is delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including an espresso maker, and will later return to Earth with experiments and trash. This was the sixth SpaceX mission to the station.

Priscilla Presley is collaborating with NBC's Today show to hold a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win a wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The winning couple will have Priscilla Presley as a witness at the event on April 23. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets. The chapel, part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside of Memphis, is located in the Westgate Hotel where Elvis performed over 830 shows. Priscilla Presley made it clear that no Elvis impersonators will be present.

Following a 2-0 win over Newcastle United with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League. Liverpool is four points behind City, and both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet have played a record-equalling 47 games this season.

Roma defeated Napoli 1-0 in a key Serie A match for Champions League qualification, ending their four-month home winless streak. Miralem Pjanic scored the lone goal in the 25th minute from a swift counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis secured the victory with numerous saves in the second half. The win moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of rivals Lazio, while Napoli extended their winless run to five games. The match was played under tight security with no reported incidents.

In an uninspired League One match, Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played to a 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. Following the dull game, Doncaster's media team created a 27-second highlights video for their YouTube channel, which featured only the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has a unique tactile relationship with his pet blood parrot cichlid, which he strokes and massages by hand. The fish appears to enjoy this interaction, actively seeking it out and returning to his hand. The bond formed after Giroux removed other bullying fish from the tank and began hand-feeding his pet. The fish now requires at least 15 minutes of daily interaction and becomes frustrated without it. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan in 1986.

Ben Stokes is a fiery and aggressive character in the England cricket team, a trait demonstrated by past incidents such as punching a locker and breaking his wrist, and clashing with Marlon Samuels. The author believes his character is an asset, provided his aggression is controlled to produce runs and wickets. His coach, Peter Moores, has spoken with him to help manage his responses. England wants Stokes to play as much as possible to help him achieve his full potential.

Wales' 33,000 sell-out Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium will take place at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12. The top two teams in Group B both have 11 points, with Belgium leading on goal difference. Following a 3-0 win over Israel, Wales is in its best position to qualify for a major tournament since 1958, leading to high ticket demand. Despite speculation, the match was not moved to the larger Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules and the team's preference for the Cardiff City Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The Young Lions are the defending champions and have been drawn in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, opening their campaign against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, with first-time call-ups for Arsenal's Stephy Mavididi and Chris Willock, and a recall for Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.

Manchester City are keen to sign 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, a top talent who has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously rejected a move to Barcelona's academy at age 12 to continue his studies. City has held discussions with Anderlecht's chairman about a compensation package as manager Manuel Pellegrini looks to build for the future.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican national and transgender escort, was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed pending further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with her in the hours before she died to come forward.

A woman named Dawn, who suffered seven miscarriages, accused her long-term friend, a convicted burglar named Jamie, of stealing £207 she had saved for a gravestone for her baby, Daniel James. The accusation was made on "The Jeremy Kyle Show," where a lie detector test confirmed Jamie had taken the money. Following the revelation, a distraught Dawn burst into tears and stormed off the stage, expressing her deep sense of betrayal over the theft.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis in northern Iraq, the majority of whom were women, children, and the elderly. The freed individuals were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to the Kurdish regional capital of Irbil. The motive for the release was unclear, although one official stated that Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate it. The Yazidis, a long-persecuted religious minority, were captured by ISIS when the group overtook their towns last summer, during which they faced extreme persecution that included killings and enslavement.

Tottenham and England striker Harry Kane, following a remarkable season, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animated video by Copa90 features his best goals and celebrations, created by layering still photographs. Titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', the video was released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane faces competition from players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Former Liverpool defender Jamie Carragher supports manager Brendan Rodgers remaining at the club despite a trophyless season and a likely failure to qualify for the Champions League. Carragher believes new players have not yet integrated and that Rodgers' future should not be decided by a single season. He stated Rodgers must make the right signings to help the team win a trophy and get into the top four next season. Separately, Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, where his 23 Foundation provides coaching in schools in deprived areas to help young people realize their goals.

A four-year-old boy's plastic Nerf gun was confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport after being deemed a risk for resembling a prohibited item. The boy's father called the security staff "over-zealous" and the checks "ludicrous." The airport defended its actions, stating they follow government regulations that prohibit items resembling replica guns, and apologized for the inconvenience, offering to post the toy back.

A 31-year-old man identified as Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. His requirements for a partner include being fit, attractive, a non-drinker and smoker, reliable, honest, loyal, good with pets and housework, and enjoying the outdoors while also being a "princess." He offers accommodation, a free gym membership, and states he is financially successful and willing to spend money on his partner. He describes himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, independent, and a successful property owner.

FA chairman Greg Dyke is proposing radical changes to increase home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and to redefine 'home-grown' as having trained in England for three years before age 18. Despite opposition from the Premier League, he is backed by five former England managers. These managers warn that the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level is detrimental to the national team, and while promising young players like Harry Kane are emerging, they lack opportunity.

In the show Poldark, Demelza gives birth to a daughter, and Ross is portrayed as a loving father. The passage criticizes the rushed timeline of the pregnancy, which moves from announcement to birth very quickly without explanation. This fast pacing was also noted by fans on social media and mirrors a previous character's pregnancy in the show.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his players to focus on their own performance and ignore their relegation rivals. Despite being bottom of the Premier League, three points from safety, back-to-back wins, including an injury-time winner from Jamie Vardy against West Brom, have provided a survival lifeline. Pearson cautions against becoming overly optimistic, emphasizing that their future is in their own hands if they concentrate on their own run-in.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia to Mexico. The journey is significant because Varvara, previously thought to be an endangered western gray whale, visited breeding grounds of eastern gray whales. This has led scientists to hypothesize that some whales considered part of the endangered western population may actually be eastern grays, suggesting the distinction between the two groups may need to be re-evaluated.

A new landmass, measuring roughly 1,000-1,640ft long, 100ft wide, and rising 30-50ft above sea level, emerged overnight off the coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island near the town of Rausu. Geologists believe a landslide, triggered by melting ice and snow, forced the seabed to the surface. Local residents reported feeling no tremors or hearing any sounds. Authorities do not expect the land to expand further and confirmed the event is not related to a recent major earthquake in Nepal.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims that he will leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, instead stating his love for the club and his desire to sign a new contract. This follows a recent falling out with his manager, Laurent Blanc, after being dropped for a Champions League match. Van der Wiel insists he is happy in Paris and is ready to play when called upon, but his future at the club could be affected by PSG's reported interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves.

Juventus striker Carlos Tevez has been told to terminate his contract with the club, which runs until 2016, to complete a return to his former team, Boca Juniors. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, has confirmed the club is close to a deal but insists Tevez must first end his contract with the Serie A champions. Although Juventus is reluctant to lose their top scorer, who has netted 17 goals this season, they have accepted his wish to leave and are identifying potential replacements. Argentina's manager, Tata Martino, has stated the potential move would have no bearing on Tevez's international future.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 in a Champions League match, overturning a first-leg deficit to secure a semi-final place. Manager Pep Guardiola ripped his trousers in excitement during the game, revealing his underwear, and joked he would need to buy new ones for the next match.

A three-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale involved ten people, including four children. Four people—a 40-year-old man, a 27-year-old woman, a five-year-old boy, and a six-year-old girl—were airlifted to hospitals with various injuries. Six others were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. Emergency crews freed one person trapped in a vehicle, and the highway was closed for several hours.

Ahead of their Premier League match against league leaders Chelsea, Arsenal's Mesut Ozil showed off his new Apple Watch on Instagram. The Gunners have been boosted by Jack Wilshere's return from a five-month injury, and he was on the bench for their FA Cup semi-final. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere is the future of the club but is held back by his fitness record, questioning if he can endure a full season without injury.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby at Old Trafford, a significant match as United recently moved above City in the league table. Clattenburg has previously sent off players from both teams this season, dismissing City's Vincent Kompany and United's Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. The teams have contrasting recent form, with United on a five-game winning streak and City struggling. Assisted by Simon Beck, Jake Collin, and fourth official Jonathan Moss, Clattenburg is regarded as one of the Premier League's leading referees.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon like a 'little black puppet on a string'. Katter claimed the government assumed Gordon would resign after he was accused of domestic violence and admitted to a concealed criminal past. Gordon subsequently quit the Labor Party but announced he will remain in parliament as an independent, throwing the government's razor-thin majority into chaos. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, defended his statement, citing his own experiences with racism and stating he used the term deliberately to expose what he saw as the government's racial overtones. The comments sparked criticism on social media over his terminology.

Nineteen-year-old Dayna Dobias, who has cerebral palsy, creates dancing videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and staring, she wants to be seen as the same as everyone else, not defined by her disability. In defiance of doctors' early predictions that she might never walk, she now dances, drives, attends college, and has begun motivational speaking at local schools.

MLS side Orlando City has expressed interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who struggled on loan at Real Madrid, as he would be a commercial draw for their large Latin-American fanbase. United are willing to sell the 26-year-old for around £8 million, while other interested clubs include Premier League sides Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, and European teams Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Separately, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira after he rejected their initial offer; clubs like Paris St Germain and Juventus are interested if he does not sign.

At a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday, at least three suspects attempted to carjack a white Dodge Charger at gunpoint. After the driver fled, the suspects poured gasoline on the car, which had two passengers inside, and set it on fire. The driver and passengers were not injured, but the car was destroyed. The incident is being investigated as an arson and the suspects remain at large.

Southern Iowa chiropractor Charles Manuel surrendered his license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He also recommended that patients stop taking medication he had prescribed. As part of an agreement, Manuel pledged not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these actions, he received perfect five-out-of-five-star patient satisfaction scores on HealthGrades.com.

A Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner," according to the Pentagon. The U.S. plans to file a diplomatic complaint over the aggressive maneuvers performed by the Russian jet. Russia's Defense Ministry countered that the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder switched off, and their jet was identifying the aircraft. This follows a similar dangerous incident a year ago, as encounters between U.S. and Russian aircraft are common.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot overnight on March 27, just days before President Obama's visit. The thief broke the car's window and used a rope attached to another vehicle to rip the locked rifle case from its securements. A gear bag, backpack, and other items were also stolen, though some were later found nearby. The rifle has not been recovered, the hotel lacked surveillance cameras, and the Secret Service was notified before the president's visit.

71-year-old Luigi Costa is accused of murdering his neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra in 2012. A forensic psychiatrist testified that Costa's brain was compromised by dementia and alcohol abuse, leading to a confused state where he would not have understood his actions. The prosecutor suggested Costa feigned his memory loss. The case hinges on Costa's mental state, as a not guilty verdict is possible if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack is proven.

In Everton's 1-0 win against Burnley, Ross Barkley missed a 10th-minute penalty that he took instead of the more reliable Leighton Baines. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision, stating he was happy for confident players to take penalties and that Romelu Lukaku would have taken it had he been playing. The saved penalty by Tom Heaton recalled a previous match where Kevin Mirallas also took a penalty from Baines and missed. Despite the miss, Everton won the game with a goal from Kevin Mirallas.

Two passengers were found dead in their cabin on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cruise line stated the deaths appear to be a murder-suicide. The bodies were discovered by the ship's cleaning staff, and the FBI is now investigating.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert has made a winning start as coach of Curacao, leading the team to the second round of 2018 World Cup CONCACAF qualifying. After winning the first leg 2-1, Curacao drew 2-2 with Montserrat in the second leg to win 4-3 on aggregate. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, previously reached the World Cup semi-finals as a player in 1998 and as an assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a decorated player who has won many major European trophies, views keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as a significant achievement comparable to winning a cup. Despite Leicester being seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic they can avoid relegation. He signed for the club in the summer and, while happy in Leicester, it is uncertain if he will stay beyond his one-year contract.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her two young children by their grandmother, Debbie, who has been their primary caregiver since infancy. Debbie, who stepped in when social services threatened to intervene, believes Gemma is unfit due to her drinking, partying, use of legal highs, and unemployment. Debbie accuses Gemma of stealing, including an iPad from one of the children, to fund her lifestyle, an accusation Gemma denies though she admits to stealing from her mother in the past. Consequently, Debbie is preparing to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children because she cannot trust her.

After Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored against Manchester United, Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed the goal should have been disallowed. They concluded that John Terry fouled Radamel Falcao in the build-up to the goal, with Souness describing it as an "elbow in the back of Falcao's head."

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway Thursday morning after a rear tire blew out. Everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated before the bus burst into flames. The fire destroyed everything in the back lounge except Scott's Bible. The band's other two members were not on the bus, and the group is still scheduled to perform at the Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space lasers to convert sunlight into energy, which could be beamed to Earth to boost solar panels and power homes. After successful initial trials in Scotland, further trials are planned in Portugal. Unlike sci-fi depictions, these lasers would not be powerful enough to be weapons. This is distinct from a separate Japanese proposal to use lasers on the ISS to clear small space debris. However, Dr. Quarterman has noted a potential concern about who would control the satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, has gone on the run after vanishing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl and for ten unrelated offences of possessing indecent images of children. Munden, who suffers from learning difficulties and autism, is the subject of an urgent police manhunt.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts to Shelly Sterling, the wife of former Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling. Shelly Sterling sued Stiviano, claiming her husband used their money to buy her gifts, including luxury cars and a duplex. Stiviano argued she did nothing wrong. The lawsuit follows a scandal in which a recording of Donald Sterling making racist remarks to Stiviano surfaced, resulting in his ban from the NBA and the termination of his ownership of the team.

Former Arsenal player and Sky Sports pundit Thierry Henry has criticized the club's recent transfer activity. He urges Arsenal to sign four top players in the summer—a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker—to have a chance of winning the Premier League. Henry cites Chelsea's successful signings as an example and specifically questions whether current striker Olivier Giroud can lead the team to a title.

Maurice Van Ryn, a former Bega Cheese boss, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including the persistent sexual abuse of a child. A young woman, one of his victims, told a Sydney court about the severe impact of the years of abuse. She stated that as a child she did not know it was wrong, kept it a secret until she heard he had been caught, and is now scared for future relationships. She has suffered depression, self-harm, and has attempted suicide. Van Ryn sat calmly in the dock and did not look at her as she gave her statement.

19-year-old Arsenal midfielder Serge Gnabry is returning after more than a year out with a serious knee injury. After recently playing 90 minutes for the Under-21s, he says he is feeling "better and better" and is now over his injury worries, looking forward to his return.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling from a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales. He ran from a taxi into the dark to avoid paying a fare he and his friends could not afford. After leaping over a fence, he became disorientated and fell. A coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco received no compensation, while the HM Passport Office made a £42 million profit and its managers were awarded bonuses of up to £3,500. Ministers rejected a blanket refund for affected families to avoid creating a precedent. As a result, only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, totaling £203,066, despite many people missing trips or paying extra for rushed documents. The Chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, Keith Vaz, expressed astonishment that so few were compensated given the agency's profits.

A three-bedroom, semi-detached "timewarp" home in Horfield, Bristol, is for auction with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. Untouched for over 80 years, the property features original 1930s elements including a mint green and black bathroom, a kitchen with its cupboards and brick fireplace, stained-glass windows, and vintage food tins. Despite being double-glazed, the potential cost of renovations may deter developers, making it an ideal property for antique lovers.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state of Germany, bordering the states of Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, and Bavaria, as well as Poland and the Czech Republic. Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge following a long illness. He was a highly influential conductor in the early-music movement, having founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he directed for 30 years. The AAM made over 200 recordings, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His other roles included artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and academic positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Tributes described him as a generous, clever, and genial man who was a founder of historically informed music and a mentor to many musicians.

In the year to March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, the lowest number for a 12-month period since 1976 and a decrease of five from the previous year. A sharp instrument, most commonly a knife, was the method used in 51% of killings. The police identified 31% of the accused as being under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the decline but stressed the need for continued efforts against violence and alcohol misuse, while Scottish Labour's Claire Baker urged caution, citing a past upward revision of homicide figures and a rise in other violent crimes.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, giving the Black Cats their first Premier League win of the season. Despite Dan Gosling giving them the lead with their first goal in three games, Bournemouth conceded to Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Manager Eddie Howe stated that a lack of confidence was not the issue, but rather the team's failure to convert the numerous chances they created.

Mr. Abbott stated that the only way to prevent migrant deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," a policy Australia enforces by detaining migrants in offshore processing camps. The New York Times editorial described this "ruthlessly effective" policy as brutal, inhumane, and of dubious legality. Separately, Mr. Abbott angered Australian Jewish groups by claiming Islamic State was worse than the Nazis because it boasts about its evil. The Executive Council of Australian Jewry called the comment "injudicious and unfortunate," highlighting the difference between terrorism and the state-led genocide of the Holocaust. Mr. Abbott stood by his remarks but said he was not in the "business of ranking evil."

The US has suspended bilateral talks with Russia, blaming it and the Syrian government for intensified attacks against civilians in Aleppo following the collapse of a truce. The US cited the targeting of critical infrastructure, including a main trauma hospital and an aid convoy, as reasons for its decision, which has left hundreds dead and about 250,000 people trapped. In response, Russia expressed regret, accused the US of shifting blame and failing to meet its own agreements, and denied involvement in the convoy attack. As a result, planned talks in Geneva were cancelled and US personnel are being withdrawn, though both nations will continue counter-terrorism discussions to avoid accidental clashes.

A think tank, Policy Exchange, with backing from Downing Street, has proposed that councils sell high-value social housing when it becomes vacant. The scheme is projected to raise £4.5bn annually, which could fund the building of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes and reduce the 1.8 million-person waiting list by 500,000. Supporters argue this is a fairer use of assets that would house more families. Opponents, including the Labour party, counter that the policy would break up mixed communities, forcing low-income families out of affluent areas and creating segregated neighbourhoods. The government's official stance is that councils already have the authority to do this and should be considering it as a way to use their housing stock more efficiently.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old man, died at his home in Swansea during a measles epidemic that has resulted in 942 cases. An examination could not confirm if measles was the main cause of his death, and an inquest will be opened for further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16. The attack was reported to have taken place in 2001, and he is due to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court later.

Promotion-chasing Gateshead, unbeaten in nine National League matches, drew 1-1 with Guiseley, who were unbeaten in five. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when Jake Lawlor scored from a James Hurst pass. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute after a slip by Guiseley substitute Derek Asamoah allowed Wesley York to score.

Bristol Sport Ltd intends to replace two stands to increase stadium capacity, an alternative to a delayed new stadium proposal. Approved by the city council, the redevelopment is scheduled to begin in May, provided a section 106 agreement is signed and no judicial review is filed by March.

The firm Cuadrilla has suspended its shale gas drilling, or fracking, operations in Lancashire following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) stated that such tremors are a known result of processes like fracking, which involve injecting pressurized water into rock. The BGS linked the recent quake to a previous one in April, confirming both occurred near the Preese Hall drilling site. Cuadrilla will now examine the BGS data and consult with authorities over several weeks before deciding whether to resume work. While controversial in the US, a UK parliamentary committee has supported fracking in the UK, provided it is tightly regulated.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool busker, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing his bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner, which gave the impression he was collecting for the charity. He was cleared of two other fraud counts. Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and that the banner, for which he had permission to display, was a tribute to the victims, not a means to collect money. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town beat Queens Park Rangers 3-0 with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. Varney scored after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance, and Lawrence capped off the scoring. The victory lifted Ipswich four places to 14th in the table, while QPR slipped to 15th. QPR offered little in attack, and their manager Ian Holloway called the second goal a "calamity" and said his team was "awful" afterwards. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his side's performance despite their recent scoring struggles.

Wells, 23, impressed in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. He stated the club is heading in the right direction, praising the exciting, elite performance environment created by the coaches.

Fifth-placed The Reds beat third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for a second consecutive win. Coach Churcher credited the victory to the leadership of Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, along with the front five making over 70 tackles. While calling the performance "dogged," he believes it was not a complete one and the team must improve. The Reds' next eight games include seven against teams below them and one against league leaders Old Elthamians.

Police in Kolkata arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun. The incident, which occurred in Ranaghat on March 14, also involved the theft of money and ransacking of a convent school. Nazrul, an alleged Bangladeshi citizen, was identified from CCTV footage and named by five previously arrested suspects. He was apprehended at a railway station after police received a tip-off that he was returning from Bangladesh. This is the sixth arrest in the case, with two of the eight identified suspects still untraced. The crime sparked outrage and street protests across India.

An interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explains why UK consumers change what they buy. Key reasons include the arrival of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video also explores how the ownership and ranking of major UK brands are changing.

Two women, one in Sandyhills and one in Stranraer, have lost money to a phone scam where callers claim to be from BT technical support. The scammers state there are internet problems to gain remote access to the victim's computer and steal cash. Police are warning the public to be very careful of cold calls requesting remote access and to never give out banking details over the phone, as reputable businesses do not ask for this information.

Scotland assistant coach Duffy, 37, has joined third-placed Championship side Featherstone on a one-year contract from Swinton Lions. He will immediately lead the team in their final league game, a move praised by chairman Mark Campbell. Duffy's former assistant, Stuart Littler, has replaced him at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and a coastguard helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach on Sunday to aid a rider with head injuries. The unconscious rider was treated at the scene before being flown to the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to allocate a radio frequency for a global satellite flight tracking system. This action by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU) addresses weaknesses in the current ground-based radar system, which were exposed by the 2014 disappearance of flight MH370. The new system will use satellites to receive aircraft transmissions (ADS-B), enabling real-time tracking of planes anywhere in the world. The UN's aviation arm, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines.

Julian Hernandez, who was abducted by his father at age five, has been found at 18 living in Cleveland. The FBI received a tip about his identity after he had problems applying for college. His father, Bobby Hernandez, was arrested and is being held in Ohio on charges including tampering with records to get a driver's license. Authorities had suspected the father since the boy's 2002 disappearance, when he fled after claiming he was taking his son to pre-school.

A fire on March 2 at a Duncan Street site, run by Asset and Land Group for Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) has suspended the company from accepting waste and revoked its environmental permit, effective August 7 subject to appeal, after the fire service raised prior concerns. The company must remove all waste from the site. Although the fire service had visited nine times in the past year and deemed the operators "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills linked to the crisis in Ukraine. The first bill would simplify the annexation of foreign territory, allowing a referendum or a plea from a territory's leaders to be enough for Russia to add it as a new subject, a change justified as necessary when a neighboring state is "disintegrating." The second bill creates a fast-track procedure for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly Russian speakers, waiving taxes, residency, and financial requirements, and granting citizenship in two months instead of a year. These actions are connected to the strong pro-Russian sentiments in Ukraine's Crimea region, where many already have Russian passports.

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 wins and 20 world championships, is currently in a significant slump, with low expectations despite having two world champion drivers. The team's history includes dominant periods, such as the Honda era with Senna and Prost in the late 1980s and the Mercedes era with Häkkinen in the late 1990s. The current decline began in 2013, initially with chassis issues and now with problems from the Honda power-unit. This recent downturn follows a period where titles dried up after 2008 and was marked by scandals like "Spygate" in 2007 and "Lie-gate" in 2009. The passage characterizes this as a cyclical pattern for McLaren, which has previously recovered from slumps under team boss Ron Dennis. Dennis, along with driver Fernando Alonso who returned in 2015, remains confident that the team's car is now competitive and that a future Honda engine will allow them to challenge Mercedes and win championships again, a belief that currently rests on the team's reputation and Alonso's career.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old from Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27. The attack occurred as he was getting into his car after leaving a gym. Three Liverpool men have been arrested and remain in custody. Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and are appealing for people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward.

For a more spiritual online Christmas, several options are available. Everyday Church Online offers global virtual services, including a Star Wars-themed Christmas sermon. Children can play the free game Guardians of Ancora, which features Bible quests about the nativity. The nativity story is also retold in online videos, such as one told through social media updates, and in a Manga comic and app called Manga Messiah. Additionally, churches use platforms like Twitter to share spiritual thoughts and connect with their communities during the festive season.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land, with an offer of 320 hectares of replacement land. There are conflicting expert opinions on the environmental impact; developers claim a biodiversity "net gain," which is disputed by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. Natural Resources Wales is not opposing the development but questions the replacement land's value. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend, and Welsh government ministers will make the final decision.

Novaya Gazeta reported that over 100 men suspected of being homosexual were detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed and some tortured. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the allegations. In response, Chechen Muslim clerics and leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the claims, with clerics adopting a resolution calling for "retribution" against the "true instigators." Novaya Gazeta viewed this as a call for reprisals against its journalists and urged Russian authorities for protection, noting its history of reporters being murdered while investigating the region. The LGBT Network is helping people flee and may take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, share a building and founder, Samir Patel. Fresh Start finds homeless clients, who are then housed by Investing Solutions in shared properties. The company claims housing benefit for each individual, with the total payout exceeding the rent paid to the landlord, thereby generating a large profit. This model, which has received over £2.1m from Wandsworth Council in two years, has been criticized by a homeless charity as a "new low" and by tenants who report poor living conditions. Both organizations state they operate legally and pass the bulk of rent to private landlords.

In their final warm-up match before the Eurobasket qualifiers, Great Britain lost to the Netherlands after leading for most of the first three quarters. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points for GB and Ben Gordon added 13, while the Netherlands were led by Worthy de Jong with 18 points. The Dutch team secured the win by scoring the first 10 points of the fourth quarter. Coach Joe Prunty was pleased with Gordon's performance but noted the team "lost a little of our fire" at times and emphasized the need for complete plays in the upcoming qualifiers, which begin with a game in Hungary.

Former five-weight world champion Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves for his 154lb boxing bout against Floyd Mayweather, deviating from the standard 10oz requirement. The NAC will debate the matter on August 16, with fighter health and safety as its primary concern. The NAC sanctioned the fight after its executive director, Bob Bennett, cited McGregor's boxing ability demonstrated against Nate Diaz, his physical advantages of being younger, taller, and longer, and Mayweather's decade-long knockout drought. In preparation, McGregor's camp hired Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez to familiarize him with boxing rules after Cortez observed a sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi, who subsequently left the camp.

The closure of the Sunday Post's London office marks the end of Fleet Street's era as the historic heart of British journalism, with its last two reporters, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, departing. For decades, the street was home to nearly every national newspaper, beginning with the first British daily, the Daily Courant, in 1702. At its peak, it was the primary source of public information and a hub of activity with printing presses, smoke-filled newsrooms, and numerous pubs frequented by journalists. The decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch relocated his papers to Wapping, leading to a year-long, violent dispute with the print unions. By 1988, most other newspapers had also left for modernized, computerized facilities. The former newspaper offices are now occupied by businesses like supermarkets and restaurants, signifying the "final deadline" for this influential period in British media history.

Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling faced abusive comments on Twitter over her political views, including a £1m donation to the 'No' vote campaign in the Scottish independence referendum. She blocked some users she believed were abusive SNP supporters, stating she would not stay silent to protect any political party's image. Rowling also noted positive interactions with other SNP supporters and joked about bringing marshmallows after a user suggested her books be burned.

A University of Edinburgh study found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and five times more likely to be on statutory supervision than their wealthier peers for the same offenses. Poverty was identified as a key factor increasing the likelihood of offending, even after other risks were considered, with those in extreme poverty more likely to be both victims and perpetrators of crime. While boys are three times more likely to be violent than girls, girls from poorer backgrounds are twice as likely to be involved in violent crime. The study concludes that contact with the juvenile justice system can inadvertently worsen the conditions that lead to violence. A separate report noted that despite overall crime falling, it remains concentrated in deprived areas with high health problems and unemployment. The Scottish government counters that Scotland is becoming safer and that it is tackling poverty and inequality.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway at the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday and later pronounced dead at hospital. Robbie Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm. It is alleged Mr Walsh and two others went to the estate looking for Mr Haugh, found him with another man, and a fight involving knives and golf clubs ensued, with other individuals joining. Mr Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Two other men arrested were released without charge, while Mr Walsh was remanded in custody. Police recovered a bloody blade, a knife handle, and other weapons.

Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan has admitted in the High Court that a tweet he posted about MP Tom Elliott, a former UDR member, was untrue and without foundation. The tweet falsely alleged that Elliott had harassed and shot people during his service in the UDR. The court heard that Mr. Elliott has a clear MoD record. As a result, Mr. Flanagan must post an apology on Twitter, while a judge has reserved judgement on the amount of compensation. The Stormont indemnity insurer has refused to cover Mr. Flanagan's costs, a decision he is challenging separately. Mr. Elliott stated he was "totally vindicated" but disappointed that the resolution took 19 months.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with over 230 staff dating back to 1874, was bought by its managing director, Benny Hartop, last year. The company has increased its weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet a surge in orders. This increase is due to better-than-expected sales of its new branded range, launched in January, and growth in its private label business. The firm sells its products across Europe and in markets including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial for striking 72-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn with his car outside a school in Kempston last December, causing her serious head injuries. Mrs. Blackburn was on duty escorting a child across the road when the incident occurred. Wright admits to hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and could not recall if the traffic light was red. The prosecution alleges his car failed to stop for a red light while other traffic had. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care, and Wright expressed remorse in court. The trial continues.

NATO is conducting an anti-submarine warfare exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose" in response to increased activity by advanced Russian submarines. In the drill, a German U-boat simulates an enemy, trying to evade ten NATO warships in a search likened to finding a needle in a haystack. The exercise employs surface ships, helicopters, and new underwater drones. It also exposes a critical vulnerability in the UK's defences due to its lack of maritime patrol aircraft, forcing Britain to rely on NATO allies to spot submarines near its waters. This gap could allow Russia to track the UK's nuclear deterrent, highlighting that some nations cannot conduct anti-submarine warfare alone and must address their defence shortcomings.

United Nations officials warn of potential genocide and ethnic cleansing in South Sudan, where violence that flared in July has caused 340,000 people to flee to Uganda, more than any other country this year. The crisis involves an average of 2,500 new refugees daily and is characterized by ethnically motivated killings, rape, and torture, with Dinka tribes targeting Equatorians and Nuer. While Uganda initially coped well by providing land and aid, it is now beginning to struggle with the nearly one million refugees it hosts, prompting a UNHCR coordinator to call for international intervention to stop the "massacre of civilians."

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. The former footballer, who turned professional in 2013, has a record of eight wins and one draw. He is the son of former champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

A new £33m Bridgwater Community Hospital is planned to replace the current cramped and outdated 1813 building. The new facility will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray and scanner space. Funding will come from a portion of the government's £330m NHS investment, with the remaining balance paid by local NHS trusts. The project, which aims for completion by autumn 2014 on land at Bowers Lane, is supported by staff who believe a modern environment will improve patient well-being and provide a "one-stop shop" for care.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe at approximately 13:35 GMT. The victim, a member of a local family who were gathering for a celebration, was in or close to a black Mercedes. He was taken to Northern General Hospital but died from his injuries. The incident follows several other recent shootings in different areas of Sheffield.

Three main hacker groups are involved in the Ukraine conflict. The pro-Ukrainian Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, use DDoS attacks, hack Russian servers for data on soldiers, monitor CCTV, and hijack printers for propaganda. The anti-Western Cyber Berkut aims to disrupt Ukraine's military plans by hacking government websites, electronic billboards, and claiming to have leaked documents from US officials and Ukrainian officials regarding the downing of MH17. The Russian activist group Anonymous International, known for leaking Kremlin documents, has also published material related to the conflict, such as letters from a Russian fighter and alleged emails from a rebel commander. These groups employ a range of tactics including DDoS attacks, website hacks, and data leaks for intelligence, propaganda, and disruption.

Ahead of the May 5th election, several veteran MSPs gave farewell speeches in the Scottish Parliament, moving Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick to tears. Former First Minister Alex Salmond stated that Scotland is "diverse, not divided," called for greater powers for Holyrood, and criticized the Scotland Bill. Labour MSP Duncan McNeil warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability, while Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie joked about a colleague. Ms. Marwick thanked Mr. Salmond for his service with distinction.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care. She is calling on pensioners, their friends, and families to share their experiences, which will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will examine factors such as health, social relationships, and the care home environment, aiming to highlight both good and poor care. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, its chair, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that the main advisory panel lacks a provider expert, calling it a missed opportunity for partnership.

Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group saw its pre-tax profit increase to £3.5m for the year to the end of June 2016, despite a fall in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures animal feed and operates 19 Country Store shops in Scotland, experienced growth in international sales. Harbro acknowledged a challenging outlook for agriculture and uncertainty around Brexit but expressed confidence in the group's position to handle future challenges.

The body of a man in his 70s was found at a house in Little Gaddesden, and police are treating the death as murder. A man in his 80s was also taken to hospital. Detectives want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, who is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. Police have warned the public not to approach him and to contact them with information, while additional patrols are being conducted in the area to reassure residents.

The IMF's second-in-command, David Lipton, has warned of a weakening global economy, a view influenced by weaker-than-expected Chinese trade data where exports plunged 25% from a year ago. The IMF now anticipates it will likely downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast in April, creating ongoing negative ramifications for businesses that depend on China's growth.

The new chain ferry at Cowes has had a problematic start since its late May launch, experiencing breakdowns, groundings, suspension due to training issues, and damage to cars. Local businesses are suffering from a loss of trade. In response, the council has made the crossing free until July 2nd and ordered an auditor's review. Compensation for businesses is under discussion, while a transport councillor has described the issues as "teething problems" for a prototype, stating that electrical and seamanship problems have been rectified and ramp extensions are being made to prevent car damage.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott on Thursday morning, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of causing death by careless driving, and the road was closed until early evening for a police investigation.

Matching Models, a London temp agency, is facing criticism for discriminatory job advertisements that specify physical attributes such as hair color and body measurements. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners have condemned the ads as "appalling," "unlawful," and in violation of the 2010 Equality Act. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defends the practice, asserting that looks are important to clients for first impressions and citing specific client requests, such as a particular cup size to fit a designer outfit. An employment lawyer confirmed the adverts are "clearly unlawful," noting they could be seen as discriminatory against older women and that men rejected for the roles could sue for sex discrimination.

An office assistant at a private school in Bangalore, identified as Mahesh, allegedly shot and killed one student, 18-year-old Gautami, and injured another, Sirisha, at a school hostel. The motive for the shooting is unclear. Mahesh was arrested following a manhunt and remanded until April 12. Incidents of gun crime at schools in India are described as very rare.

A Glaad analysis of shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with the number of transgender characters rising from seven to 16. The group noted that more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, thanks to shows like *Empire*, *Luke Cage*, and *How to Get Away with Murder*. Glaad's president acknowledged progress but stated that numbers are "only part of the story".

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced he will not seek re-election. This decision follows criticism and expected deselection by his local party over a missing £10.25m loan. The loan was made to Northampton Town FC by the borough council when Mackintosh was its leader and is now the subject of a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. Mr Mackintosh has denied any wrongdoing.

Police officer Roy Oliver, 37, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards by firing a rifle into the teen's car as it was driving away from a party in Balch Springs. Initial police claims that the car reversed "aggressively" towards the officer were discredited by footage showing the car moving forward. Oliver was subsequently fired and charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault for the other teenagers in the car. He faces a potential sentence of 5 to 99 years in prison, and a conviction would be the first for a Dallas County police officer for murder since 1973.

Melania Trump and her son Barron will delay moving to the White House to allow him to finish the school year, a decision that has drawn both public criticism and support. While historians note that presidential families have sometimes prioritized children's schooling over an immediate move, it contrasts with recent practices of the Clinton and Obama families. This choice suggests Melania Trump may not take on a full-time public role as First Lady, leading to speculation that her step-daughter, Ivanka Trump, could assume some official duties, a move with some historical precedent.

Following the death of a 72-year-old man in Inverness on October 27th, the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to his call.
