Police Scotland is fully engaging with the investigation, and a report on the findings will be submitted to COPFS.

A yellow wind warning has been issued for the counties of Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys, forecasting gusts up to 75mph. The unusual easterly direction is expected to increase the impact and cause likely disruption to road and sea travel. A tree has already fallen in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants defeated the Panthers 4-3. After the Panthers tied the game twice, the Giants took a 4-2 lead with goals from Mike Radja and James Desmarais, though Nottingham's David Ling scored a late goal. The teams will meet again on Saturday. In the league, Nottingham leads with 28 points, Sheffield Steelers have 27, and Belfast has 25.

Nico Rosberg won the Chinese Grand Prix, while his championship rival Lewis Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, and made five pit stops, leaving him with a 36-point deficit. Sebastian Vettel finished second after colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap in an incident-packed opening that also involved Daniil Kvyat, who finished third. Daniel Ricciardo took the lead at the start but fell back due to a puncture on lap three. Hamilton's progress was hindered by significant car damage sustained in the first-lap chaos.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality after his career ended, stating he wanted to advance a topic he felt was ignored in German football. His announcement was widely praised by fellow players, football administrators, and government officials, who called it a courageous and important step in the fight against homophobia. The event is seen as a watershed moment in a sport that has struggled with the issue, with hopes it will encourage others to come out and break down the taboo.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, is hoping to sign a new contract with Brighton after his current deal expires. He helped the club achieve promotion to the Premier League by making 32 appearances this season. Believing he has played well enough to earn a new deal, Sidwell wants to be part of the team in the top flight next season. Brighton, who are now also contending for the league title, confirmed their promotion with a recent win over Wigan.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool after 12 minutes, and Kurtis Guthrie equalised for Colchester United from a corner after 17 minutes. Colchester missed chances to retake the lead, with Sam Slocombe saving a shot from George Elokobi and Guthrie heading against the bar. Blackpool also missed a chance to win when Tom Aldred headed wide. The game ended with Colchester United down to 10 men after Sean Murray was shown a straight red card in injury time.

Footballer Reid, 29, has joined Colchester United after making 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season prior to their relegation from League One. He has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, and could make his debut for Colchester against Aston Villa in the EFL Cup on Wednesday. Colchester's season started with a 3-1 defeat to Accrington.

Following the murder of PC Keith Palmer, the UK Police Memorial Trust is constructing a £4 million national memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, expected to be completed by 2019. The memorial will honor more than 1,400 police officers and staff killed on duty over the past 250 years, featuring a brass screen that provides leaf-shaped mementos for their families. The project is funded by a £1 million government commitment and an appeal for £1.5 million by the trust.

Following a 1-0 win at Sunderland, Manchester United are 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left. Manager Alex Ferguson stated the team's focus is on upcoming games, like the derby against Manchester City, and not on their record of 25 wins in 30 matches. Due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea, Ferguson will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea, though Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez will be available. Ferguson credited the win over Sunderland to determined defending.

Google's chairman, Eric Schmidt, stated the company pays the "legally required" amount of UK taxes and it is the government's responsibility to change the tax system if it wants more. He expressed perplexity at the debate and argued corporate tax should be levied where economic activity occurs, not where products are consumed. In response, Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggested a new committee to oversee major firms' tax affairs, potentially in secret, to prevent them from hiding behind confidentiality rules. The passage also notes that EU leaders have agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an automatic information exchange between tax authorities.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce the NHS's £3.6bn agency staff bill by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap, introduced in October, limits payments to agency staff to 55% above normal shift rates and has so far saved £600m. Despite this progress, the NHS is still behind schedule. Future measures include publishing performance "league tables" for trusts and collecting data on the highest-paid agency staff to combat overcharging, such as one trust being quoted £130 an hour for a surgeon against a £76 cap.

Longford, a town symbolizing Ireland's economic crash, is showing early signs of recovery according to local traders. Business owner Matt O'Brien notes an increase in trade after his shop diversified into childrenswear and dress hire, though he suggests that eliminating street parking charges would further help. Politically, the opposition party Fianna Fáil criticizes the government for not prioritizing broadband and for the Industrial Development Authority's failure to bring any foreign investment clients to Longford in over four years. The government points to the planned Center Parcs development, which could create 1,000 jobs, as a positive step for the region. The overall message is that while the midlands is beginning to recover, more effort is still required.

An eight-team competition concludes on 29 May, with the top four sides qualifying for the play-offs. Player statistics list Warner as the leading run-scorer (294) and McClenaghan as the leading wicket-taker (9). Four current or former England players—Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen—are participating in the tournament. The passage also provides a detailed schedule of fixtures and results from 25 April up to the final.

Plastic bag use has increased by 200 million since 2013, with discarded bags causing environmental problems by ending up in landfills and rivers. To address this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags from October to encourage reuse. Similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have already reduced bag usage, and campaigners hope the new fee will lessen waste and help the environment in England.

A yellow weather warning for wind across Wales on Friday caused significant disruption. A school roof was ripped off at Rhosgadfan, hundreds of homes experienced power cuts, and train services between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead faced delays. Irish Ferries cancelled six sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, and speed and lane restrictions were implemented on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle, and Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed. The winds eased by Friday evening, lifting the bridge restrictions.

Michael B. Jordan is "super excited" to join the film "Black Panther," scheduled for release in February 2018. The film reunites him with his "Creed" director, Ryan Coogler. Jordan, who has not specified his role, is also looking forward to working with co-stars Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, who is currently playing the title character.

The east wing of Alexandra Palace is undergoing a £26.6m restoration to become a cultural destination. The project includes the 1875 theatre, unused for decades but with original features intact, which is planned to reopen in 2018 for performances, cinema, and music. The BBC studios will also be repaired, and the east court will become a public space. Funding is provided by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, which is raising the final £1m.

The 30-year-old former Manchester City player, Milner, won 61 senior caps for England after debuting in 2009 and holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46. A squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships, he scored his only senior international goal against Moldova. Milner announced a decision he described as "common sense," wishing the England team future success.

A fire started by rubbish in a wood stove destroyed the Smith family's home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, killing their dog and cats. The family escaped only because their son, David, was awake on FaceTime and saw the flames, alerting them after the fire alarm failed to sound. The family fled with only their pyjamas but has received donations of clothes and other necessities from the community. The mother credits her son with saving her and her daughter's lives.

An energy drinks giant is reportedly considering a £200m offer for West Ham United. The club's current majority owners, Sullivan and Gold, purchased their stake in 2010 for £105m and now own over 85% of the club. Since moving to the London Stadium, West Ham has also been linked with takeover bids from Qatari and Chinese groups. The owners have indicated a minority stake could be sold to clear debts, but they intend for ownership to pass to their children.

An awards ceremony, noted as being different from the Oscars, combined fan-voted categories with promoting summer blockbusters. *The Fault in Our Stars* was the big winner, taking Best Movie, while its star Shailene Woodley also won Best Female Performance, the Trailblazer Award, and Best Kiss. Other major winners included Bradley Cooper for *American Sniper*, Channing Tatum for *22 Jump Street*, Meryl Streep for *Into the Woods*, and Kevin Hart, who accepted the Comedic Genius award with his children. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award from his *Avengers* co-stars, and the event showcased clips from upcoming films like *Pitch Perfect 2* and *Ultron*.

St Mirren, who are at the bottom of the Championship, have signed Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 international. Smith was previously on loan at Dundee United from Aberdeen, where he made 89 appearances. St Mirren boss Jack Ross called Smith a brilliant acquisition and a good player who provides another attacking option.

Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months, as the weather is now warm enough. Extra staff will also repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while working on pipework. Supervisor Steve Innes stated they worked for hours without proper personal protective equipment because the area was assumed safe and were only informed of the contamination later. The workers now have cancer fears and are undergoing blood tests, with Mr Innes claiming EnQuest failed in its duty of care. EnQuest confirmed the exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level and has taken additional precautionary steps. Wood Group said it prioritizes safety and supported the investigation. The Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers, while the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) did not investigate as the incident was not reportable under regulations.

The Asian Civilisations Museum (ACM) is returning a $650,000 bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari, which it purchased in 2007 from a dealer whose manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The decision to return the item followed an official request from India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), and the museum plans to seek legal compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicentre in Garfagnana. The tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence and was followed by aftershocks. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but phone lines and power were cut in the Garfagnana area, and schools were evacuated. The quake occurred in a region prone to earthquakes, where two tremors the previous May killed more than 20 people. The passage also references the 2009 L'Aquila earthquake, which killed almost 300 people and led to the manslaughter conviction of six scientists and an ex-official for providing falsely reassuring statements before the event.

Austin Grant from Sheffield, who had been dubious about South Yorkshire's climate, has finally grown a fruit on his plant. The unripe fruit has made the 62-year-old grandfather, who was "literally jumping for joy," very happy with the results.

Rockstar has delayed the game's release from January 27th to March 24th to allow for extra testing and polish. The company also announced that online heists will be released on consoles before the PC version. Screenshots and minimum specifications for the PC version have been published, promising support for 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor configurations.

76-year-old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his painting "Squint (19)". The 7ft-high work depicts a leper squint, which are holes in medieval churches allowing undesirables to view services. Judge Ansel Krut described the piece as "extraordinary" and technically subtle. Simpson, a previously shortlisted artist, plans to spend the prize money on art supplies. Established in 1957, the John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards.

In Istanbul, the offices of two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked almost simultaneously by masked assailants. Gunfire shattered windows at both locations, and a fire was set at the Yeni Safak building but was extinguished. There were no casualties, and police are hunting the attackers, though no group has claimed responsibility.

A 24-year-old ex-Burton player will join the Mariners on a free transfer from the Stags on January 1st, becoming manager Marcus Bignot's first signing. He previously spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances.

Arsène Wenger, who has been linked to the England manager job, is focusing on his current role while supporting interim manager Gareth Southgate. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to secure the permanent position. Wenger also announced that Arsenal will offer defender Hector Bellerin a new contract, stating his long-term future is at the club. In other news, midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. A joint inquiry is being conducted by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive, with the company fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf has announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-running pay dispute. The RMT union had claimed some crew on freight boats, operated by Seatruck for Serco Northlink, were paid less than £4 an hour. Under the new arrangement, Serco Northlink will resume direct operation of the service from next month, ensuring all crew members will be paid at least the national minimum wage.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, who had intervened in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother Samantha, pleaded guilty to common assault following a confrontation. Both Jamie and Samantha Mitchell also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to police about the events, later claiming the incident was a "tragic accident" when Jamie tried to push the couple apart. A jury returned a verdict at Winchester Crown Court, and the pair are due to be sentenced on 6 February.

Songwriter Rod Temperton, nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, died in London at the age of 66 following a brief illness with cancer. Temperton penned major hits for his band Heatwave, including "Boogie Nights," and wrote several key songs for Michael Jackson's breakthrough albums "Off The Wall" and "Thriller," such as "Rock With You" and the title track "Thriller." He also wrote for artists like Anita Baker and Donna Summer, won a Grammy Award, and received two Oscar nominations. His death prompted tributes from many notable musicians, including Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson.

A team of international researchers, including from Swansea University, has discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, or geoglyphs, possibly 2,000 years old in the western Brazilian Amazon. The sites were revealed by modern deforestation and their function is not well understood; they were likely not villages or defensive structures, but possibly used as sporadic ritual gathering places. Soil analysis suggests the geoglyphs were built among tall vegetation and were not visible above the forest canopy, which raises questions about their purpose. The research challenges the assumption that the Amazon was pristine before European arrival, indicating that for 6,000 years humans created a "prehistoric supermarket" by cultivating useful trees rather than burning large forest areas. This ancient agroforestry may have left a lasting legacy on the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests.

Australian Nick Kyrgios, 21, beat Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 to advance to the second round of the Shanghai Masters. The world number 12, who recently won the Japan Open, said he was bored and tired during the match, citing travel, poor sleep, and his recent success as reasons. The passage also mentions Kyrgios was fined at the same tournament last year for an outburst.

Scientists and charities are urging the Welsh government to vaccinate boys against the human papilloma virus (HPV) to protect them from increasing cases of head and neck cancers, which are affecting younger, non-smoking men. While girls are already vaccinated to prevent cervical cancer, the Welsh government is waiting for recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering an extension of the programme to boys.

Fifteen-year-old Jak Trueman, who had a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, has passed away. Since his diagnosis last August, he documented his life and treatment on a popular Facebook page called "Jak's Journey," which attracted widespread support. The West Calder High School pupil briefly attended a school prom held in his honour, met with football stars, and received awards for his courage. In January, doctors stopped treatment after his cancer spread throughout his body. Following his death, his family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and a charity football match was planned in his memory.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a drab Group D match. Substitute Abdallah El Said scored the winning goal in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a goal correctly disallowed for offside. The win keeps Egypt in contention for the top spot in the group, while Uganda are eliminated from the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, a town without a station since 1956. In partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, the plans could provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The preferred location was chosen for its size, allowing for future expansion, and its good highway access and connectivity. The council will now begin the process of acquiring the land.
Police found plants in an "elaborate grow house" during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries in Hamelin after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Following an emergency operation, she was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner has handed himself in to authorities and is in custody. Both the victim and suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin, and the motive for the attack is not yet known. Police have secured the area and are calling for witnesses.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but men are 25% more likely to get one. The research, based on 4,600 Australian workers, found no evidence for the "reticent female" theory that women avoid asking for more money. A professor concluded there is "some element of pure discrimination against women." However, the study also found that men and women under 40 ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate, suggesting negotiating behavior is changing.

Oxford City Council has been unable to find a new burial site despite spending money on ground investigations. The two remaining cemeteries, in Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. All identified council sites have been discounted due to size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants. After these cemeteries are full, burial options will be limited to reopening family plots and interring ashes. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway from July 19-22, will offer a new augmented reality app. The app allows users to scan physical items like signs and posters to access online content, including videos and band interviews. This feature is designed to enhance the experience for both on-site visitors and a global audience, enabling them to interact with the festival and its acts, such as The Waterboys and Imelda May.

A 10-year-old horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, which is a rare occurrence that can happen in horses with no underlying health issues. While Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia, he showed no such symptoms on the day of the race. The sport's authorities are investigating the incident to understand its cause and prevent it from happening again.

Davina Ayrton, a 34-year-old transgender woman formerly known as David, has been remanded in custody after being found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, will be sentenced on March 4th and is likely to be held in a male prison. The judge remanded her, citing a risk to herself and that she might fail to attend court. The victim clearly recollected the assault, during which she shouted at Ayrton to stop while two other people were asleep nearby.

A Serbian doubles team lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. The day before, Novak Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Prior to the Olympics, Djokovic had a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon to Sam Querrey but came back to claim his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

More than 20 international competitors are set to compete in a chainsaw carving event on Saturday in Carrbridge, Cairngorms. Using only chainsaws, they will carve logs into animals and people. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, is returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Welsh rugby player Webb is recovering from a serious foot injury and aims to return before the Six Nations in February, potentially earlier than planned. He has also renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region.

US border agents near Sumas, Washington, disrupted a smuggling attempt involving two men carrying 58 pounds of ecstasy from Canada. After being confronted, one man, Nathan Hall, fired at agents and fled to Canada where he was later arrested, while the second man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately apprehended. Two additional suspects, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were arrested for their roles in planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco, with Lambert expecting to be paid $11,000. All four face conspiracy and drug charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service counselled over 4,500 children for online abuse in the past year, a significant increase from about 2,400 in 2011-12, with the true number of victims believed to be far higher. Children as young as seven reported being tormented, abused, and scared to go to school. According to Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, these figures are a wake-up call, as cyber-bullying can follow children home and become inescapable persecution. She urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene, for schools to take the problem seriously, and for children to ask for help. The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week.

The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction as illegal and an obstacle to a two-state solution. Israel's Prime Minister Netanyahu was infuriated, accusing the US of helping draft the resolution, which the US state department denied. Israel responded by summoning ambassadors and recalling some of its own. To avoid further straining relations ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry, Israel postponed a planned vote on new settlement homes in East Jerusalem at the request of the prime minister's office. Kerry is expected to lay out his vision for peace and address Israeli government critiques, while Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas stated the resolution paves the way for an upcoming French peace conference.

On the eve of Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, Prince William paid tribute in a BBC interview, calling her a "guiding example" of a good monarch. He also addressed criticism of his work ethic, stating he takes duty seriously but is finding his own way into the role. Political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron, also offered tributes. The Queen began celebrations by visiting Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and opening a new bandstand. A new stamp featuring four generations of the Royal Family was released. Further planned events include the unveiling of The Queen's Walkway, lighting beacons, and a lunch with the US President and First Lady. The republican group Republic criticized the BBC's coverage of the celebrations as not being fair and balanced.

West Ham United, a Premier League side, defeated League Two's Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match. Two quick goals before half-time from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew gave the visitors control. Cheltenham, who were unchanged from their previous league defeat, had chances including a volley from Harry Pell and a header from Jordon Forster, but could not score. The loss ended League Two's representation in the competition.

Motorcyclist Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 after driver Andreas Werner failed to spot him while turning. Werner, 46, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family stated they saw no value in a jail sentence, accepting it was a momentary lapse, and Werner was described as remorseful.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from London, traveled to Syria to fight with the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. He was a prominent online propagandist, posting recruitment videos and gruesome images, including one of him holding a severed head. After faking his own death online, he attempted to sneak back into the UK with his cousin's help but was arrested at Dover. Khawaja, who police consider one of the most dangerous returning British jihadists, admitted four offences and faces a possible life sentence.

22-year-old Kayden Jackson has signed for Barnsley from Wrexham, turning down a new contract with his former club. He scored four goals in 36 appearances last season and is Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season. Barnsley's caretaker manager, Paul Heckingbottom, stated that Jackson's pace and attacking style will fit in nicely with how the team plays.

Sealed bottles of 'Vanish' detergent have washed up on several Cornish beaches, including Poldhu Cove, prompting National Trust volunteers to clear them due to the risk they pose to wildlife. It is suspected that a container went overboard from the ship MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather near Land's End in May, but the Maritime and Coastguard Agency states the link is currently circumstantial. Conservation groups are highly concerned about the impact on marine life, and the public is advised to keep a safe distance from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale at around 14:00, causing minor injuries to several people. The road was closed and a diversion was put in place via the A897. Police Scotland have stated that inquiries into the incident are ongoing.

Bolton Wanderers' 28-year-old French centre-back, Dorian Dervite, has signed a new contract following the club's promotion to the Championship. He made 14 appearances last season to help secure promotion, with his manager praising his excellent contribution. He follows teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in signing a new deal.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour parties, who previously cooperated to defeat the government on Brexit amendments, have experienced a breakdown in their alliance in the House of Lords. The split occurred after MPs rejected their amendments, with the Lib Dems determined to insist on them while Labour chose to defer to the Commons. This led to mutual accusations; the Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding to a "hard Brexit", while Labour sources called the Lib Dems' actions "grandstanding" that gave people "false hope". Although the parties have a history of collaborating on other issues, a Labour source predicts "residual tensions" following this dispute, while a Lib Dem peer stated they will continue to work with others on issues they agree upon.

Defence is a low priority in the UK election for both politicians and the public, despite a more dangerous global environment. Consequently, UK defence spending is falling, with the country projected to drop below the NATO 2% of GDP target, creating capability gaps such as the lack of Maritime Patrol Aircraft. Future governments are likely to make more defence cuts due to deficit reduction, though parties are constrained by their own commitments. The expensive renewal of the Trident nuclear deterrent faces political disagreement, and new aircraft carriers risk being under-equipped and under-crewed, challenging the UK's ability to project power.

FC Barcelona is under investigation over the transfer of striker Neymar, for whom they initially paid a fee of £48.6m, though the total cost is alleged to be £106.8m. Following accusations of misappropriation, president Sandro Rosell resigned, and a Spanish judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue the investigation. To address the matter, Barcelona made an additional tax payment of €13.55 million to cover potential interpretations of its fiscal obligations, while denying any tax-related crime and stating it believes its original payment was correct.

27-year-old Michael Luciw died in a crash caused by an elderly driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on a motorway. Mr Luciw's family and the driver of the van he was in are calling for mandatory driving or medical tests for older people, arguing that reactions slow with age. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must renew their licence every three years via a self-assessment form with no test. However, the DVLA has no plans to restrict licences based on age, stating evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK supports older people driving for as long as possible to maintain their independence.

Following reports of debilitating side effects from transvaginal mesh implants, an independent review in Scotland concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse and that patients should be given a range of treatments. The report was deemed "watered-down" by two patient representatives and a consultant who resigned from the review group in protest. The Scottish government will implement the report's recommendations, including mandatory reporting of adverse events, but stated it cannot ban the procedures as that power lies with a UK regulatory body. An independent expert has now been appointed to review the process that led to the controversial report.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5,000m record in Glasgow with a time of 14:49.12. McColgan initially questioned if the race met record criteria, as Muir was the only 5K competitor and she was unsure about drug testing protocols. British Athletics confirmed the record is expected to be ratified, stating drug tests are not required if no doping control is present. Following this, McColgan expressed excitement, stating Muir has the potential to run faster and win world medals, and compared the race to her own record-breaking run. Muir also broke her own British 1500m record in August and reached the 1500m Olympic final in 2016.

Jung won gold riding Sam, a late replacement horse. Silver went to France's Astier Nicolas and bronze to American Phillip Dutton. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th after his medal bid was ruined by a disappointing cross-country performance, despite having led after the dressage phase and producing a faultless show-jumping round. Fox-Pitt was competing just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Briton Andy Murray defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 to reach the last 16 for the 11th time. In a tense match played in fading light, Murray saved five set points in the fourth set, winning five consecutive games to claim victory after two hours and 39 minutes. Fognini, who was penalized for an obscenity and appeared to have an ankle injury, had been close to forcing a fifth set. Murray will next play Frenchman Benoit Paire. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also reached the second week for the first time with a win over Maria Sakkari.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was ordered to close for three months after a sudden death occurred there and police found evidence of alcohol being served until 04:49 BST. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, fined £3,000, and criticized by a judge for her "appalling record". James Thomas was charged with one count and fined £1,000.

Ulster Unionist leader Mike Nesbitt made controversial remarks at his party's manifesto launch, advising voters to transfer their support to the nationalist SDLP after voting for his party, as he prefers a partnership government with them over Sinn Féin. This shifted the election's focus away from the party's intended referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and caused a colleague, Danny Kennedy, to publicly distance himself from the comments. Nesbitt defended his statements without regret, claiming support while canvassing. He also stated the election should be a vote against the "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and... corruption" of the current DUP and Sinn Féin leadership. The party's 'Real Partnership' manifesto includes policies on tackling health waiting lists, increasing police numbers, prioritizing infrastructure, supporting the LGBT community, and protecting groups from Brexit-related harm.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed a motion will go before the Northern Ireland Assembly to pardon gay and bisexual men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. This will align Northern Ireland with England and Wales' "Turing's Law," allowing for pardons both posthumously and for living individuals. After securing executive agreement, the minister stated the move will right past wrongs and ensure equal treatment, and the motion will now be considered by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish runner, finished second in a 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, breaking the Scottish record and moving to second on the British all-time list. The veterinary student, who was pleased with her first 1500m race of the season, now holds the Scottish records for both the 1500m and the mile. She hopes to secure an Olympic place at the upcoming British trials.
The passage contains pictures of 26 Scottish beaches ranked as "most excellent" for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi likely poisoned Alexander Litvinenko with polonium-210 in London in 2006, causing his death three weeks later. He argued the Russian state was probably the sponsor of the plot, as the suspects had no personal motive and the use of polonium indicates state involvement. Potential motives included Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his attacks on President Putin. The suspects deny wrongdoing, but extradition attempts have failed and they remain in Russia. Horwell also noted Litvinenko was poisoned twice and the public health risk from the polonium will never be known.

Following Michael Clarke's retirement after an Ashes defeat, 26-year-old Steve Smith has been named the new Australian Test captain, with David Warner as his vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh endorsed the decision, citing Smith's talent and Warner's maturity. Smith, who already captains the one-day and Twenty20 sides and has prior Test captaincy experience, will lead the team in the upcoming limited-overs matches.

Mr. Farron repeatedly refused to state whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead saying "we are all sinners." He affirmed he is "passionate about LGBT-plus rights," that defending equal marriage will be "at the top of my agenda," and that he wants to extend marital rights for transgender people by removing the "spousal veto." He explained his vote against the 2007 Equality Bill was due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties" after a proposed amendment was defeated, while maintaining his support for "equal access under law for all people whatever their sexuality."

Accord Healthcare is reopening a Fawdon drug manufacturing plant previously closed by Sanofi in 2015. The global pharmaceutical company plans to use the facility for production, hoping to rehire former staff and bring skilled jobs and long-term investment to the local economy.

Richard Ellis, the council's acting deputy chief executive and former interim director of corporate governance, is leaving at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing via a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Opposition leader Stephen Flynn stated the departures indicate the council's inability to retain senior staff, while council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their dedication.

Militants from the so-called Islamic State (IS) group attacked the Sardar Daud hospital in Kabul, detonating explosives at the gate before opening fire on staff and patients. After several hours, commandos killed all four attackers, while more than 50 people were wounded. The Taliban denied involvement. The attack signifies a change in approach for IS, marking their first direct engagement with security forces in the capital and suggesting they have expanded resources and military training. President Ashraf Ghani condemned the attack as trampling human values.

After crashing at the TT and experiencing mechanical problems with his Honda Fireblade, rider Martin has stated he will not do any more road racing on Hondas for the rest of the year. He did not compete in the North West 200 and has been withdrawn from the Ulster Grand Prix because he believes the bike is uncompetitive. He described the TT as a "bloody disaster" and now wants to race classics and oddball bikes.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared governor posts in Nigeria's elections, delivering the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which also lost the presidential election, won eight governorships and is now considered a regional party with support mainly in the south-east and Niger Delta. The APC secured most northern states and the commercial hub of Lagos. However, the APC's failure to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states is a major concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari due to the risk of militant disruption to oil revenue. The PDP's decline is attributed to voter desire for change, corruption allegations, and its failure to end the Boko Haram insurgency. Despite some incidents of violence, the elections were considered more peaceful than in previous years.

A report by the environmental group Mighty accuses Singapore-based Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of unwittingly encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to regional haze. Mighty's report claims Olam created a "secretive market" for rogue suppliers and is also responsible for deforestation in Gabon. Both Olam and Temasek reject the allegations. Olam's CEO asserts the company has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and that non-compliant suppliers will be removed from its supply chain. Temasek states it supports no-burn policies but, as a matter of governance, does not direct Olam's operations. The passage notes this conflict occurs within the palm oil industry's broader troubled track record regarding deforestation and other environmental issues.
A restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law was introduced permitting dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they are outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is a doubt with a knee injury, Derby County striker David Nugent could return from a groin injury, and midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring a late goal.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube, with the telecom regulator stating it was no longer necessary after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the site. According to Pakistan's ministry of information technology, Google created an online process for the PTA to request the blocking of offending material, which YouTube would then restrict within the country. YouTube clarified that government removal requests are not automatic and are only granted after a thorough review if content violates its guidelines or is deemed illegal; all such requests will be recorded in its Transparency Report. The ban was originally imposed in 2012 by the Supreme Court following the upload of the film "Innocence of Muslims," which sparked deadly protests. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the news, some activists are demanding greater transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the government.

LFA boss Musa Bility is demanding that Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, withdraw from his role due to a perceived conflict of interest. Bility argues that because Scala shares a Swiss-Italian nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino, he should step down, citing a precedent from the 2015 election where Scala did so. Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. A spokesman for Scala counters that sharing nationality is not a conflict of interest under FIFA regulations and that the 2015 withdrawal was a voluntary precaution because the conflicting candidate was the incumbent president, a situation not present in the upcoming election with five candidates and no incumbent.

Daniel Timbers and Barry Joy were killed at Harford Attachments on Monday morning. The incident, which took place in a paint-spraying area, is believed to have been a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes that ignited. Police and the Health and Safety Executive are investigating the deaths.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against Caf regarding a contentious refereeing decision in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea. This was resolved after Tunisia apologised to Caf. Meanwhile, Morocco's participation was in doubt after they were banned for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears. The Court of Arbitration for Sport later overturned this ban and reduced a fine. As a result, both Tunisia and Morocco are now set to compete in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifiers.

Following a mass fracas in the 95th minute of a game Chelsea won 3-1, Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off. Aguero received a four-match ban for a violent challenge on David Luiz, while Fernandinho got a three-match ban for clashing with Cesc Fabregas, who will face no further action. Both clubs have been charged and have a deadline to respond.

Wales has some of the highest cancer mortality rates in the developed world, partly due to long delays in diagnosing patients without clear symptoms. A new six-month pilot scheme, inspired by Denmark, is being introduced in Cwm Cynon and Neath Port Talbot to address this. The scheme allows GPs who suspect a patient has cancer, even without obvious signs, to refer them to a dedicated diagnostic center within seven days for rapid testing. The aim is to achieve earlier diagnosis, improve patient outcomes, and if successful, roll out the service to other health boards.

England defeated Pakistan by a large margin of runs at Old Trafford to level the series. Joe Root was named man of the match after a dominant performance that included scores of 254 and 71 not out, four catches, and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's innings, while former player Michael Vaughan called the win an "absolute hammering". Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment, citing poor shot selection and a lack of confidence for his team's performance.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Consequently, forwards coach McBryde will become the interim head coach for Wales for their summer tour, a role he has fulfilled twice before. The Welsh Rugby Union is in the process of appointing assistant coaches to support McBryde and believes the involvement of Welsh coaches with the Lions is a valuable opportunity that will benefit Welsh rugby in the future.

Hull City came from behind to beat Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. After Charlie Austin gave Southampton an early lead from the penalty spot, substitute Robert Snodgrass inspired Hull's comeback. Snodgrass, on for an injured Will Keane, scored and then provided the free-kick assist for Michael Dawson's header in two second-half minutes. Hull's first league win since 20 August was secured by saves from goalkeeper David Marshall and a late goalline clearance from Sam Clucas, although the team remains in the bottom three.

A fatal crash involving a motorcyclist and a tractor occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The local motorcyclist was killed, the tractor driver was uninjured, and the road was closed. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses.

Macedonian President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, stating he acted to "put an end to the agony" and "defend national interests" before early elections. The recordings, released by opposition leader Zoran Zaev since 2015, allegedly show government ministers involved in vote-rigging, murder cover-ups, and widespread corruption. The move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials; Zaev called it illegal and urged protests, while EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn said it was not in line with the rule of law and put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The government denies the accusations and accuses Zaev of trying to destabilize the country, a charge he rejects.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Swansea is seeking a new manager, with Paul Clement as the top choice. Curtis, who is temporarily in charge, warns that relegation would be difficult to recover from, contrasting with the club's previous rise from near bankruptcy to the Premier League. He attributes the decline to frequent managerial changes since Michael Laudrup left, a dilution of the "Swansea Way" playing style, and the inadequate replacement of departing players. Despite this, Curtis believes the current squad is good enough to stay up, which he stresses is crucial for the club and the local area.

Leyton Orient defeated Dagenham & Redbridge 3-2, a result that kept Orient's play-off hopes alive while relegating Dagenham to the National League. After Orient went 2-0 up, Dagenham equalised through goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, but Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner for Orient. Dagenham, who had League Two's worst goal difference and struggled in attack, will now be led by manager John Still in an attempt to gain promotion. The victory for Orient came four days after player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his role, with interim manager Andy Hessenthaler in charge.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to the club as a youth coach in February in his first job since retiring as a player. Manager Jürgen Klopp described the appointment as "wonderful news" and said Gerrard wants to be a manager in the future. Gerrard, who is working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, had previously been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but felt the opportunity came "too soon".

Morton took a 2-0 lead with goals from McManus and a deflected strike by Ross Forbes. After Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa before half-time, further goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable win for the hosts.

Ofsted found children being taught in squalid conditions at three illegal schools in Birmingham which have now been closed, with the owners investigated. This was part of an investigation into 18 unregulated schools, and the Chief Inspector of Schools, Sir Michael Wilshaw, stated this is likely the "tip of the iceberg" and that children are at risk of abuse or radicalisation. Running an illegal school can lead to a jail term of up to 51 weeks. The government is consulting on new regulations for places teaching more than six to eight hours a week and has funded a team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups. The Education Secretary intends to seek prosecution against identified unregistered schools.

Lilliard Gin is a new small-scale distillery at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, the first in the region in almost 200 years. It uses local, wild botanicals from the Teviot valley to capture the Borders "terroir". Named after a legendary heroine from the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, the name was chosen to reflect the landscape and the female-led production team. The distillery is considered a step towards making the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence".

Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal driving limit, killed Harry Whitlam by reversing a tractor into him at Swithens Farm in August 2013. Jailed for 16 months, Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation for failing to ensure the safety of others, as the incident was on private land. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, said her family had been "changed forever" and hoped her son's life would be remembered for more than the day of the accident.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) modified the ban on Uruguayan striker Luis Suarez for biting an opponent. CAS upheld his nine-match ban in competitive international games but ruled that preventing him from all football-related activities was excessive. As a result, he can now train with his new club Barcelona and play in friendly matches, though he still must serve his competitive match ban. His legal team called the appeal a success, while the world players' union, Fifpro, expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not more strongly diminished.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-metre carrying race featuring obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. The event is open to various competitor combinations, not only married couples. Their victory qualifies them to compete in the World Championships in Finland.

The paper car tax disc system is being replaced by an electronic system in October 2014, leading to concerns about potential job losses for the DVLA's 5,000 employees. Minister Stephen Hammond stated that while job roles will change, any reduction in staff will be handled through redeployment to other areas of the business, not redundancies. Local AM Mike Hedges, though disappointed about fewer job opportunities, welcomed the commitment to redeployment, believing it would reassure DVLA staff.

The EU objects to three Hungarian laws concerning asylum seekers, higher education, and NGOs. Hungary's Foreign Minister, Mr. Szijjarto, stated the country will not backtrack on these "domestic issues" and that the EU should not interfere. The asylum law involves housing seekers in secured containers, the education law threatens to close the Central European University, and the NGO law would stigmatise them as "foreign-backed." In response to potential EU sanctions, including stripping Hungary of its voting rights, Hungary has secured Poland's promise to veto any such move. Thousands of Hungarians have protested the laws, and the EU has warned it will take action if there are no positive developments.

A new live-action "Beauty and the Beast" film is set for US release on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson will star as Belle, alongside Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Kevin Kline as Maurice. An unnamed star will play Mrs. Potts. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a Sunday Times columnist since 1993, has died after being diagnosed with what he called the "full English" of cancers. Hailed by his editor as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper, Gill was known for his dazzling and fearless writing, which he dictated due to dyslexia. He was also a controversial figure, having made numerous offensive comments throughout his career. At the time of his death, he was engaged to his long-term partner Nicola Formby and had previously been married to Home Secretary Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator, suffering serious head and brain injuries that left him in a 10-day coma. The assault followed a performance where he wore a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a symbol of eternity in Mongolia that predates its Nazi association. The suspect is an unidentified Russian diplomatic officer. The Russian embassy is investigating and claims press reports are distorted, while Mongolian police confirm the case is under investigation and state the officer was not detained because the injury was not considered serious, not due to diplomatic immunity. The rapper's lawyer, father, and band member denied social media reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler".

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area after protesting against an airport's expansion plans on the northern runway at 03:30 on Monday. They will appear in court on August 19th, and airport security will be reviewed.

In a cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire, Glamorgan's total was dominated by Nick Selman's 101, a welcome return to form after a string of low scores. Despite his century, Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles consistently took wickets in helpful, cloudy conditions. After Glamorgan were bowled out, Gloucestershire began their innings and struggled in the evening gloom, leaving the day's play evenly balanced. The passage also notes that Glamorgan were captained by Michael Hogan due to an injury to Jacques Rudolph.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested after he made online threats to a crisis center about a plan to ambush and shoot police officers. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and was remanded in custody pending sentencing. Hughes, who was drunk when he made the threats on two separate occasions, has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm and was on bail for other firearms offences at the time of the incident. His legal team stated he did not intend to carry out the threat.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire by 19 runs, preventing them from reaching Lord's for the first time since 2002. After being reduced to 8-2, Surrey recovered to score 255-7, thanks to a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire’s run-chase was undone by Stuart Meaker, who took three wickets in nine balls, including key batsmen Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite 68 from Tim Bresnan, Yorkshire were all out for 236.

A 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, was taking on water after its pump failed. The crew radioed for help at 07:00 BST, and an RNLI lifeboat crew provided a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Scottish runner Muir will miss the Commonwealth Games in Australia because her veterinary medicine studies and May exams conflict with the April event. The 24-year-old, who recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, is prioritizing her degree. She is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March and plans to compete in at least two more Olympics.

Football pundit Robbie Savage states that Liverpool are "miles away" from repeating last season's title challenge and that qualifying for the Champions League should be considered a success. He argues their decline is due to the sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge, with their replacements deemed not good enough and lacking the work-rate to press effectively, resulting in fewer first-half goals. The team's set-piece threat has also diminished, and the defense remains a weak link despite significant spending, lacking a leader. Goalkeeper Simon Mignolet is criticized for not commanding his area. Savage believes Steven Gerrard faces a physical and mental battle to extend his career, particularly with recovery speed, but remains a key player who should stay at the club. For the upcoming match against Chelsea, Savage predicts a Liverpool loss, suggesting a specific lineup and stating that Chelsea are "on a different planet."

A new £45m facility will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock to house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council intends to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock who was passionate about education. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for works like the Laidlaw trilogy, was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster.

Following the discovery of a British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s near Gourock, three streets were evacuated as a precautionary measure. Residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors, and exclusion zones were established on a nearby river and at sea, causing ferry disruptions. The Royal Navy plans to move the deteriorated mine to a safer location for disposal because its explosive content is unknown.

UK Sport has allocated £345m for the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics, a decrease from the Rio cycle. This has led to funding cuts for several sports, with badminton, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby losing all support, and cycling facing a major reduction. Despite winning a Rio bronze medal, Badminton England called the decision "incomprehensible". UK Sport justified the cuts as a necessary prioritization to protect medal potential and maintain success, setting Team GB a target of 51-85 Olympic medals. Funding for new sports added to the Tokyo program is yet to be decided from a remaining £9m budget.

A plan to replace three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area with a new four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks has been approved by councillors. The applicant, The East Cliff Project LLP, will demolish the hotels for the development, which supporters argue will boost tourism and provide housing for older people. The plan faced strong objections from English Heritage, residents, and the Ancient Monuments Society due to its scale and the loss of buildings that contribute to the area's historic character. Despite these objections, councillors voted in favour of the development.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier in Brecon for training, was fatally punched and beaten by Jake Vallely. The attack on May 8th, captured on CCTV, occurred after Vallely had been on a drinking binge and boasted he was the "hardest man in Brecon". Vallely will be sentenced on December 8, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter. Pte Boyd's family remembered him as a loving "all-rounder" with a promising career cut short.

Following an election day error where voters were missing from poll lists at all 155 stations, Barnet Council's chief executive, Andrew Travers, left his post by "mutual agreement." An independent investigation has been launched into the problems, which Mr. Travers blamed on electoral registration lists. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes, and appointed Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton as the temporary replacement. The council's review will conclude by the end of May and will also assess arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies gave the Tynesiders the lead with a free-kick, but Sean Newton levelled for Wrexham before half-time with a set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead with a header. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby attributed the win to a better second-half performance, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills was disappointed with his team's second-half play and missed opportunities.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of over-60s in 96 countries. Norway ranked highest, while Afghanistan was the worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb, partnered with Airbus, is building a satellite constellation of at least 600, and potentially over 2,000, spacecraft to provide global broadband. The project necessitates a shift to high-volume, low-cost manufacturing, using new assembly lines akin to car factories to produce satellites for under a million dollars each. A large-scale launch campaign will deploy the satellites, with nearly 300 expected in orbit by the start of 2021. To mitigate space debris concerns, the company commits to de-orbiting satellites within two years and includes hardware for active removal. OneWeb faces competition from companies like SpaceX but believes it has a first-mover advantage, and the project is economically significant to the UK.

Scottish government minister John Swinney stated that the UK government's spending review imposes "unprecedented pressure" and real-terms cuts on Scotland's budget, forcing tough choices, but he pledged to protect key services like schools, hospitals, and the police. The UK government countered that Scotland will receive £390m more in spending next year, rising to £750m with its own underspend, and accused the Scottish government of focusing on grievance. Scottish Labour criticised Mr Swinney's "anti-austerity posturing" and called for a long-term budget that provides a real alternative.

Changing Places toilets are enhanced facilities with extra space and equipment like hoists and changing benches, designed for people with severe disabilities who cannot use standard accessible toilets. A shortage of these facilities causes significant distress and isolation for over a quarter of a million people in the UK and their families. Although guidelines recommend installing them in new large buildings, they are not a compulsory requirement, leading campaigners to petition for mandatory building regulations. While businesses face logistical and financial barriers due to the toilets' larger size, successful installations, such as at Arsenal Football Club, have been positively received.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations, supported by European and US unions, has filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's. They accuse the company of abusing its dominant market position by forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees under long contracts, allegedly leading to higher prices and poorer consumer choice. McDonald's defended its business model, stating it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees. The European Commission will now study the submission and may launch an investigation.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh was created to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down. Joshua was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when doctors discovered and removed a large tumor during an appendix operation. The campaign began on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where his father works, and quickly went viral, being seen by over 79,000 people worldwide. A mystery donor also paid for a billboard with the hashtag to be erected in Holywood, showing the extensive global support for Josh and his family.

As part of a UK military reorganization, Brecon Barracks is proposed for closure, a move condemned by local MP Chris Davies. He highlighted the site's long history since 1805 and its concerns about the area's high unemployment and potential damage to its military tourism industry. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced the wider plan, which includes creating a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, while Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith agreed restructuring was necessary but warned it would cause uncertainty. The barracks' 85 civilian and 90 military staff are not believed to be at risk, and nearby facilities like the Sennybridge training ground are unaffected. The reorganization also confirms the closure of Cawdor Barracks in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025.

The UK fishing industry, which heavily supported Brexit to escape the EU's Common Fisheries Policy, hopes to regain control of its waters and increase exports. However, a House of Lords report warns that the industry, despite its small economic size, must not be marginalised in negotiations. The report highlights a critical trade-off: maintaining tariff-free access to the EU market, where most UK fish is sold, may require allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. Despite these risks, industry representatives are optimistic about managing their own waters, while the government aims to secure both single market access and a fair, sustainable fisheries policy.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaked documents detailing extensive US surveillance. The documents show the NSA has mass access to phone records from companies like Verizon and, through a program called Prism, information from the servers of nine major technology companies, including Google, Facebook, and Apple. US officials defend the programs as essential for national security and preventing terrorism, but the tech companies deny involvement. Privacy advocates express concern, noting that because much global data is stored on US-based servers, the surveillance can affect non-US citizens, a point that has raised questions in the EU and UK. Snowden stated he acted because he found the extent of surveillance "horrifying," while officials maintain a balance must be struck between security and privacy.

OpenAI is a venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aiming to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity without financial obligations. This follows warnings from figures like Musk and Stephen Hawking that AI could pose an existential threat, though other experts believe the risk is remote. The organization, funded by a $1bn pledge of which only a small fraction will be spent soon, states its goal is to ensure AI is an extension of human will and is broadly and safely distributed.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, a Doncaster-based soldier seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch. Following this, he received over 5,000 Facebook friend requests, a surge in mail, and numerous invitations, which his mother described as a "phenomenal" response that left him buoyed. Despite a brain injury that initially took his speech and left him using crutches, he is described as determined and humorous, now speaks unaided, and raises money for military charities as a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits.

In 2011, the US poverty rate was flat at 15%, affecting 46.2 million people after three years of increases. Real median household income fell by 1.5%, while income inequality rose by 1.6%, the first annual increase since 1993. Conversely, the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7%.

Short-format specialist Jos Buttler has signed a new contract with Lancashire, keeping him at the club until 2019. His coach, Ashley Giles, praises him as a talented player whose presence was a factor in the team's T20 Blast final win and who benefits the squad with his experience. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League, will return to Lancashire for an upcoming T20 Blast home game.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and are for sale. The government's Disposal Services Authority is handling the bidding process, which has a final decision expected in the spring. The authority wants to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to test the country's industrial capacity, aiming for the best financial return. No preservation bids have been submitted, though a local MP has advocated for saving at least one ship, potentially as a tourist diving reef. The Type 22 frigates were powerful surface combatants with a crew of around 280.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced instability from racial and political tensions, leading to four coups that harmed its economy and international reputation. This resulted in a suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009, though Fiji was reinstated after holding elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians, who now form a small majority, and Indo-Fijians, with deep segregation persisting between the groups. Economically, Fiji relies on sugar and tourism but has a diverse economy including mining and services, though it suffers from persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a major per capita recipient of aid.

Syria missed a deadline to surrender its chemical weapons, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad citing attacks by "terrorist groups" on shipments. He insisted Syria is committed to its agreements, while the US expressed concern that only 4% of the 1,300-tonne stockpile has been removed. Russia has set a March 1st deadline for the weapons to be transferred to the coast.

Mekdad also denied government forces used barrel bombs in Aleppo, calling US condemnation "absolutely unacceptable," despite reports from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and Aleppo Media Centre of hundreds of civilian deaths. Furthermore, there are conflicting accounts about Aleppo's central prison; activist groups claim rebels have seized it, but Syrian state media says the attack was thwarted. The prison is reported to hold at least 3,000 detainees.

For the 46th Booker Prize, the first open to all authors writing in English, six books are shortlisted. Neel Mukherjee's *The Lives Of Others*, set in 1960s Calcutta, is the 5/2 betting favorite. Other nominees include former winner Howard Jacobson for *J*; Ali Smith; Americans Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler, whose *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves* is the best-selling book on the list; and Australian Richard Flanagan. The list has been criticized by a professor as "weak," who believes Jacobson's book is the strongest but may not win due to reluctance for a repeat winner so soon after Hilary Mantel. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, with each shortlisted author receiving £2,500.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing to the UK Supreme Court to prevent The Sun on Sunday from naming him in a story about alleged extra-marital activities. After a High Court judge refused an injunction, the Court of Appeal initially granted one to protect his identity in England and Wales. However, the Court of Appeal later ruled PJS was unlikely to get a permanent injunction because the story had become widespread online and in other countries, making confidentiality "probably lost". The Supreme Court has agreed to hear the case, and an interim injunction will remain in place until the conclusion of the hearing.

Fosse Park was recently purchased by Crown Estates for £345.5m. The new owners are preparing plans to improve the park by addressing parking and traffic congestion, as well as its "tired" appearance and the quality of common areas. These improvements are being coordinated with the Blaby District Council, which supports the plans and views Fosse Park as a significant gateway to the city.

The release of Disney's live-action "Beauty and the Beast" was delayed in Malaysia for a content review due to a "gay moment" in the film. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film for screening with a minor edit concerning the scene, granting it a P13 parental guidance classification. Although the content is now approved, a new release date has not been announced, as scheduling is not under the LPF's jurisdiction. The decision to review the film was criticized by netizens, and local cinemas offered refunds for pre-purchased tickets. The controversial scene involves the character LeFou coming to terms with his feelings for Gaston.

Landlords in Southampton letting properties to more than three unrelated people require an HMO licence, but many are deterred by the £1,000 cost despite fines up to £20,000, leading to an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs. A shortage of affordable housing forces tenants into these unregulated properties, where they frequently report fears of eviction and poor maintenance. National mandatory licensing applies to larger properties, but Southampton's scheme covers specific areas. While most landlords cooperate, the council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

After an election where no party won a majority, Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are trying to form a minority government to avoid a second election. The main sticking point is water charges, which Fianna Fáil wants removed immediately while Fine Gael sees a role for them. A potential compromise is a commission to consider the future of Irish Water.

A fire broke out on the ferry Sorrento about 27km from Mallorca while it was travelling to Valencia. The blaze, which began on a car deck, forced a full evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats. Rescued individuals were transferred to other ships, including the ferry Puglia, and are on their way to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were injured, one of them seriously, and were taken to hospital by helicopter. The cause of the fire is unclear, and the ship may sink.

The June 8 general election saw a record 46.8 million registered voters and the highest turnout since 1997 at 68.7%. However, a significant proportion of the 4.9 million applications received were duplicates, with a net increase of only 1.4 million registered voters. This issue stems from the national online registration service and the 381 local electoral registers being unconnected and using different databases, preventing people from checking their status online. The resulting administrative burden and concerns about potential double voting, a criminal offence in a general election, have been highlighted by the Electoral Commission. The Commission recommends joining up the registers and adding a verification function. Labour has warned against measures that could make it harder for students and young people to register, noting that some can be lawfully registered at two addresses.

Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former NFL star, is believed to have killed himself in prison. In the 1990s, he was a celebrated player at the University of Nebraska before a professional career was marred by trouble. After the NFL, he was convicted of assault for driving his car into a group of teenagers and for assaulting a former girlfriend. At the time of his death, Phillips was serving a sentence of more than 30 years and was awaiting trial for the murder of his cellmate, Damion Soward. His former college coach described him as an intelligent person who had anger issues and could not overcome the demons in his life.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and the mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for good behaviour. He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams, a tradition dating back to 1858. Officially classed as a soldier with his own army number and pay, he has also taken part in public duties like switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in a Europa League quarter-final at Anfield after a remarkable comeback. The win, culminating in an injury-time goal from Dejan Lovren, was achieved through what the passage describes as a "sheer force of will" and a refusal to give up. This performance embodied manager Jurgen Klopp's philosophy of "turning doubters into believers," which was also reflected in the intense atmosphere created by the supporters. The result places Liverpool in the competition's semi-finals and moves them closer to a return to the Champions League.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee, the UK government's Mr. Davis proposed monthly meetings with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to create a "two-way information flow" on Brexit negotiations. However, Scotland's Mr. Russell called for greater transparency, stating the UK government has not made its strategic intentions clear on remaining in the single market or customs union. Mr. Russell emphasized that single market membership is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. Additionally, the Scottish government intends to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal regarding how Article 50 will be triggered.
