A study at the University of Nottingham is monitoring a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four that are genetic twins to Dolly the sheep, to determine if clones age in a normal way and remain healthy. The research addresses concerns that the cloning process may transfer "age-memory" from an adult donor cell, potentially leading to premature aging and diseases like osteoarthritis, which Dolly developed. The sheep are undergoing a battery of tests for aging-related conditions, and despite their age (approaching nine and ten years old), they are currently reported to be in good health.

Trainer John Gosden's Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes on soft ground and will now go to the French Oaks at Chantilly instead of the Epsom Oaks, where her stablemates Enable and Coronet will run. Gosden is undecided about running his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes due to ground concerns and the short time before the Derby. In another race, William Haggas's Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes.

Amid the upcoming EU referendum, the British pound experienced volatility, falling against the dollar, euro, and yen. This was driven by polls showing the "Leave" campaign ahead or a tight race, which caused the "volatility index" to hit 2008 financial crisis levels. Stock markets in Asia and London also fell, with analysts predicting further uncertainty and noting hedge funds were short-selling sterling. The Leave campaign countered that the pound had simply retreated to March levels and argued a weaker pound would benefit UK exporters, citing a recent narrowing of the UK trade deficit.

Braintree, known as The Iron, are sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off spots, after their losing streak extended to three games with a defeat to Barrow. Manager Cowley remained positive, acknowledging the tough circumstances of a long journey and an early goal against a very good Barrow team who extended their unbeaten run to nine games. Cowley called his part-time team's achievements "remarkable" and stated that while this is their toughest challenge, they will embrace it.

Starting in April 2015, planning decisions in Northern Ireland will shift from the central Planning Service to local councils, giving elected politicians the final say on most developments. Proponents like Michael Corr view this as a democratic opportunity for local communities to shape their own plans. However, critics, including Friends of the Earth, raise concerns about potential discrimination and a repeat of 1960s issues, citing a "tradition of close relationships between developers and political parties." This has led to arguments for greater transparency in political donations to prevent undue influence, a move some local politicians oppose, with the ultimate decision on the matter resting with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air weapon in Winchburgh, resulting in the amputation of her back leg. Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, voiced concern about the incident occurring in a housing estate with children. The Scottish SPCA's Chief Superintendent Mike Flynn called the shooting "alarming" and stated it highlights the need for the urgent implementation of air weapon licensing by the Scottish government. This advocacy follows a recent government consultation in which 87% of respondents opposed the licensing plan. The Scottish SPCA is seeking information from the public about the incident.

Liverpool signed striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa by triggering a release clause, making him their second most expensive signing. The move was intended to revive the team's attack after a season of poor goalscoring. The Belgium international, who scored 49 goals for Villa and returned from an Achilles injury to score 15 times last campaign, expressed his happiness and ambition to win trophies. Former manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge both praised Benteke, describing him as a "brilliant number nine" and a "massive presence" who will score goals and improve the team.

A study found no clear evidence that tablet use improves academic results, though their use in schools is widespread and growing. Tablets are currently used in the majority of primary and secondary schools, with the number of devices in schools expected to nearly double by 2016. While a definitive link to improved results is not possible to establish, head teachers reported positive impacts, and tablets may help motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement. A separate study suggested touch-screens are particularly useful for helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The research also highlighted the pervasive nature of technology in young people's lives, with many pupils taking devices to bed for social media and some describing themselves as internet "addicts."

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs documenting the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. Curated by Kay Jones from the museum's collections, the images serve as a social history, illustrating how childhood has changed over more than a century. The selected photographs capture a range of experiences, from play and special occasions to the reality of child labor, reflecting both the good and bad aspects of growing up in the city.

The Gulls have signed two players: 27-year-old centre-back Anderson and 21-year-old striker Keating. Anderson left Barrow by mutual consent to join the Gulls, a move his manager made for his leadership. Keating, who is moving from Irish leagues pending clearance, was signed for his youth and hunger. The signings come as the Gulls are four points above the relegation zone.

Bolivia has passed a law permitting children as young as 12 to work with parental authorization, a measure the government states reflects the country's poverty and the reality that over 500,000 children are already working. The legislation also sets harsher penalties for violence against children, such as a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. This new law conflicts with International Labour Organisation standards, which is reviewing the legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations.

50-year-old actress O'Donnell suffered a "widow maker" heart attack after experiencing chest aches, nausea, and fever. She researched her symptoms online, took aspirin, and saw a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. Although she did not call emergency services, she now warns women to know the symptoms and call 911.

A boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was fatally stabbed in an alleyway in Kenton after attending a party. While an earlier altercation involved youths denied entry, Che was not part of that initial fight and was targeted later, around 00:30 GMT. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and remains in a stable condition. Police have arrested a 21-year-old man and two boys, aged 15 and 16, on suspicion of murder, along with a 14-year-old for possession of an offensive weapon.

Faced with poor cancer survival rates and long diagnostic waiting times, especially for cases with vague symptoms, Denmark reorganised its patient diagnosis system. The new model has three routes: a fast-track for patients with obvious "alarm" symptoms; diagnosis centres for those with vague symptoms to prevent delays between GPs and specialists; and "yes-no" centres offering quick scans for minor symptoms to rule out serious disease. This approach has resulted in better cancer survival rates, better organisation of resources, and improved collaboration between doctors. A team of experts from Wales, which has a similar health system, visited Denmark to learn from this model.

Following the UK government's decision to disband the OFT, Powys council will take over the responsibility for issuing warnings and banning orders against dishonest estate agents or those breaching the law. The public will still complain to their local trading standards department, who will prosecute but will refer cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys. Powys will receive £170,000 a year to deliver this service.

Following a Nuffield Trust review, NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the NHS workforce to address staff shortages. The plan involves nurses and pharmacists taking on additional tasks traditionally performed by doctors, such as filling in for hospital doctors or GPs. This is intended to cover gaps in junior doctor rotas and help GPs with increasing patient numbers, particularly with a shift towards managing long-term conditions. While supporters see opportunities for improved care and staff development, unions and the British Medical Association caution that the move must not be a cheap or quick fix, stressing the need for dedicated training funds and that doctors' expertise remains essential.

A crash on the A36 Lower Bristol Road in Bath at 03:00 GMT led to a road closure until 14:00 GMT, causing disruption for commuters and bus services. Investigations into the collision are underway. Bus services are gradually resuming, with a full service expected by the evening commute.

A dispute exists between regulator Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and developer Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) concerning the environmental impact of the proposed £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon. NRW estimates the project would cause annual death rates of 21% for salmon and 25% for sea trout, based on the best available evidence. TLP disputes these figures as having "no clear scientific basis," stating its own expert modelling shows a worst-case scenario of 2% death for all fish species. The project, intended as a test bed for larger lagoons, is under review by the UK government, while the Welsh government is supportive but seeks clarity on the project's future.

Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster has announced the creation of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland. Developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board, the body will provide strategic leadership and coordinate marketing for the industry, which employs almost 100,000 people and is a key sector for economic growth. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement but noted that the new body could have implications for other organizations.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public to plant trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon. This event is part of a four-year, UK-wide project to plant millions of native trees to commemorate those who died in WW1. The goal for Brackfield Wood is to plant 40,000 trees as a tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The trust is providing saplings for volunteers to create a living tribute that will be a place for wildlife and public reflection.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her thriller "Someone Else's Skin," a novel about domestic and honour crime featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. The book was praised by judges for being powerful, finely written, and well-plotted. At the same event in Harrogate, US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career creating the detective VI Warshawski. Paretsky was recognized for changing perceptions of female crime writers by creating a strong female protagonist and for founding the organisation Sisters in Crime to support female authors.

Cricketer Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, will rejoin Worcestershire Rapids after the ICC Trophy in June. His previous season with the county in 2016 ended early when he broke his finger in his second game, an injury the director of cricket called a "massive blow" to the team's qualification hopes. Santner expressed frustration about the injury but is looking forward to making an impact. The passage also notes that Worcestershire signed Australian bowler John Hastings for the 2017 season.

Millionaire Barry Pring, 47, was unlawfully killed in Kiev in 2008 when a speeding car with stolen plates hit him as he tried to hail a taxi. A coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating the evidence was "overwhelming." His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who had briefly left him to retrieve a glove, is the primary suspect. She attempted to claim his assets, sold his possessions, and was having an affair, according to the inquest. His family and a close friend believe he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run for his money. Ukrainian police relaunched a murder inquiry in 2011, but the case is no longer actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, a boy from Merseyside who has been ill since age three, requires experimental T-Cell Therapy unavailable in the UK after a previous transplant failed. An anonymous donor has paid for his treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital in America. His family is extremely grateful, and the treatment is scheduled to start as soon as possible, with a date expected next week.

Following the theft of celebrity photos from iCloud using third-party software, Apple has extended its two-step verification to cover backups. This opt-in security measure requires a code sent to a trusted device after a password is entered on an unrecognized device, blocking the previously used hacking tool. The owner of the software confirmed the measure's effectiveness but raised concerns about the risks of the recovery key being lost or stolen. A security expert countered that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all users. Apple stated it plans to more aggressively encourage users to turn on this feature and to improve security awareness.

Mark Wright, a 30-year-old former non-league footballer and reality TV star, is in a deal to buy a 20% stake in Billericay Town and become a club director. The club, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week and has signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Following a BBC investigation into working practices, Mr. Ashley has been asked by the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee to give evidence about the treatment of his workers. The committee's chair, MP Iain Wright, has given Mr. Ashley until 21 March to accept one of several offered dates for a public meeting. The committee has warned that if he fails to agree to attend, it reserves the right to take further action, including seeking a complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has not commented on the matter, though the company has previously pledged to review worker rights.

Colleagues of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, led by Ilya Yashin, have completed a report entitled "Putin. War." The report compiles known facts to accuse President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. Contradicting Russia's official denial, the report alleges that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in securing major rebel victories, with Russian generals directing the main battles. Evidence includes testimony from soldiers, documentation of military units, and financial details such as soldier salaries and a total conflict cost of 53bn roubles. The report's origins lie in Nemtsov's investigation into unpaid compensation for families of dead Russian soldiers, who are now too scared to speak publicly after his assassination. While the opposition accuses Putin of orchestrating the war to boost his popularity, they acknowledge he was successful in this aim. Publishing the report is challenging, and it may face the same fate as previous works by Nemtsov, which, despite praise from critics, failed to galvanize protests, partly because many Russians find the country's involvement acceptable.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Rotherham, was found dead with head injuries at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones complained he was not consulted on the Article 50 letter before it was published, stating the devolved administrations were treated with a lack of respect. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns responded that the letter's contents had been discussed for months and the UK government must act in the interest of the whole UK. Although the letter promised consultation on returning EU powers to devolved administrations like Wales, significant questions remain about which specific powers will be transferred and whether funding will accompany them. Carwyn Jones has expressed fears that money will not be provided after 2020, and the exact powers to be devolved are currently unknown.

On Friday night in Newry, two cars were damaged and PSNI officers were attacked while carrying out their duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin said he was "appalled by mindless attacks," and the PSNI appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

American Apparel founder Mr. Charney was ousted last year following employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. In response to his defamation lawsuit, the company filed court documents citing evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts from Charney, claiming he violated harassment policies. The board stated it would never rehire him due to the risk. Mr. Charney's lawyer argues the company's statements are false and an attempt at extortion. A restraining order has also been issued to prevent Mr. Charney from making negative press statements about the company.

Great Britain will face Greece at London's Copper Box in a rematch of a game Greece previously won 92-64. This is Great Britain's only home warm-up before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017, and they have a chance for revenge with three key Greek players missing. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app, and after this match, the team will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland for their final warm-up games.

A journalist recounts securing an early iPhone for a BBC report after its Steve Jobs-led launch, a decision that drew complaints for over-hyping a product. The author defended the coverage by comparing the iPhone’s potential impact to the Model T Ford, a comparison now seen as justified. The passage identifies the smartphone as the key transformative technology of the last decade, putting powerful computers in billions of hands. While cameras and mobile internet existed on prior phones, the text credits the iPhone’s success to its user-friendly interface, which made these features accessible. The author uses the shift from difficult, slow photography with an SLR to instant sharing on a smartphone as a prime example of this revolution, concluding the launch marked the start of the mobile connected era.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, multiple cats have died after ingesting a toxic substance, with one case confirmed as antifreeze poisoning. The RSPCA is investigating and is unsure if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. An RSPCA inspector has appealed to the public to safely store chemicals and clean up any antifreeze spills.

The Syriza government in Greece is poised to implement further austerity measures as part of a third bailout, yet there are no public protests. This lack of protest may be the calm before the full details of the deal are revealed or a result of a "there is no alternative" mindset following the country's near-economic collapse in July. Greece is suffering from a vicious economic squeeze due to both fiscal and monetary austerity, with bank closures restricting credit. Despite this, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras remains popular. For the bailout to lead to genuine recovery, the text concludes that creditors must offer significant debt forgiveness and avoid a triumphalist attitude.

Actor Ross Kemp will briefly return to *EastEnders* as his character, Grant Mitchell. The return is for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, who will be killed off from cancer. Kemp's role is to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for her last moments, a storyline he accepted because Windsor is a close friend.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, who was obsessed with 24-year-old Alice Ruggles, stalked and fatally attacked her. Her parents immediately suspected Dhillon when police informed them of her murder. Alice's mother expressed guilt for having told her daughter to ignore the stalker and for dismissing a warning that he would kill her. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Alice's parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking.

French firm EDF approved the £18bn funding for the Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant, but the UK government unexpectedly launched a further review, delaying its final backing. The project, which includes one-third funding from Chinese investors, has faced criticism over its escalating costs, environmental damage, and foreign involvement. Supporters argue the plant is necessary for the UK's future energy supply, as it is expected to provide 7% of its electricity. The project has also raised financial concerns for EDF, leading to resignations within the company.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with. Family lawyers argue this encourages conflict and complexity, despite the form's guidance stating it is not normally necessary. The Ministry of Justice maintains there is no obligation to name a third party. If a person is named, they become part of the court case, which can delay proceedings, increase costs, and is viewed unfavorably by judges.

A conflict exists in Wales between commercial forestry and environmental policy. The forestry industry, represented by Confor, argues that ministers are prioritizing the environment over timber production, leading to a loss of 16,000 hectares of commercial forest since 2001. Despite the industry's value of over £450m a year to the Welsh economy and high demand for timber, bureaucracy has resulted in only 90 hectares being planted last year, far short of the 20,000 hectares needed annually. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social goals, promoting native broadleaf species and public access, while conservationists claim commercial forests are bad for wildlife. The government cites its Glastir scheme and "Woodlands for Wales" strategy as methods to achieve this balance.
A boy was badly injured after being struck on Bank Street in Coatbridge at about 16:40. He was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Veterans of the World War II Arctic Convoys were awarded Russia's Ushakov medal for their service. The convoys delivered crucial supplies from Britain to the Soviet Union, helping to defeat Germany, but were considered the 'worst journey in the world' due to extreme weather and enemy attacks, resulting in over 3,000 deaths. The British Foreign Office initially blocked the Russian awards due to rules on foreign medals, but later granted an exception, allowing the presentations to commence in 2013 after a long campaign for the veterans to be recognized.

An HM Inspectorate of Probation report found significant failings in the "community payback" unpaid work scheme for offenders, citing delays in sentences starting and a failure to enforce attendance. The report, which reviewed 100 cases, noted that organizational difficulties in getting offenders to attend were a long-standing problem. While some high-quality work and positive offender experiences were praised, the Chief Inspector of Probation stated that much of the management was "simply not good enough" and called the scheme a "wasted opportunity." The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement, such as reducing the number of offenders turned away from work and better matching tasks to individual circumstances. The Ministry of Justice accepted all the recommendations and confirmed it was already taking action to address the issues.

Comedian Russell Brand is accused of hypocrisy for campaigning to help the poor while living in a luxury home. When questioned by a reporter about his wealth, he responded defensively. Brand acknowledges the charge but argues it is a distraction from the real issues of economic disparity. He states that while personal change is necessary, individual gestures are futile without systemic change, and he continues to advocate for addressing inequality.

Biologist and entrepreneur Dr. J. Craig Venter, whose sense of urgency stemmed from his service in the Vietnam War, developed a faster method for gene sequencing using RNA. He left the public sector to form private institutes, including Celera Genomics, which raced the Human Genome Project to map the human genetic code, a move that drew criticism from the scientific community for its commercial approach. After the genome project, Venter's J. Craig Venter Institute created the first synthetic life form, an organism called Synthia. He has also conducted oceanic expeditions to sequence marine microbes and envisions synthetic life forms could help replace oil and capture carbon dioxide.

A survey of approximately 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children who ate school lunches tried new foods at school. Consequently, half of the parents reported their children asked for these new foods to be made at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, whereas aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The School Food Trust commissioned this research after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents avoided school lunches, believing their children were too fussy. According to experts, school meals help children try new things, and positive peer pressure at school encourages them to eat a wider variety of foods. School meals in England must now adhere to strict nutritional guidelines, with about four in 10 primary school children eating them.

Álvaro Morata is a 23-year-old Spanish striker who began his career at Real Madrid before joining Juventus in 2014. In two seasons with Juventus, he scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in back-to-back Champions League finals. His transfer to Juventus includes a buy-back option for Real Madrid of up to 30m euros. He has scored three goals for Spain at Euro 2016.

The 30-year-old footballer Wilson is currently without a team after being released by Forest in May. He had rejoined the Championship side from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, making 51 appearances in his second spell. His career has also included spells at Preston North End and Notts County, in addition to a previous four-season stint at Forest.

British retailer Tesco is selling its loss-making US chain, Fresh & Easy, to private equity firm Yucaipa. The deal involves the transfer of 200 stores and 4,000 employees, while the remaining 50 stores will close. Tesco will loan the new business £80m as part of the £150m cost to exit the US market, and it has an option to buy a stake in the business if it becomes profitable.
An individual overcame racial abuse, considered representing France, and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

A new inventory of French Alps glaciers, conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues, reveals a significant retreat. The ice-covered area shrank from approximately 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s, a 26% loss over 40 years. This research, presented at the AGU Fall Meeting, utilized map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs with manual verification. The retreat is not uniform; the southern Alps have experienced the greatest losses, which researchers attribute to lower elevations and drier climatic conditions compared to the north. These findings mirror accelerated glacier loss observed elsewhere in the Alpine region.

The Scottish women's football team has won all five of its qualifiers and can secure a place in the Netherlands finals with a victory against unbeaten Iceland. Player Evans of Bayern Munich expressed the team's desperation to qualify after previous play-off losses, describing another failure as "heartbreak." The team's strength is attributed to its 12 players who compete in top leagues abroad; Evans believes this experience in competitive environments like Germany's Bundesliga improves the players and adds different styles to the national team. The upcoming matches against Iceland will likely decide the group winner.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London alleging online harassment over a two-year period. Released on bail until mid-September, Mr Campbell stated the allegations relate only to "some tweets" which are not threatening and remain publicly visible. He accused a newspaper report of using "maximum innuendo" to encourage speculation and emphasized that nothing more sinister has occurred.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) wants Skegness to replace its Jolly Fisherman mascot, which the group claims represents animal cruelty like fish being impaled and crushed in nets. Peta has suggested a new mascot, a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," to rebrand the town as a progressive destination. However, Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, has stated that the beloved mascot is seen as happy and friendly, not cruel, and he sees no reason to change it. The original Jolly Fisherman was a poster commissioned in 1908 by a railway company to promote the resort and has become an iconic symbol of Skegness.

Georgia's Vasil Lobzhanidze scored first, but Scotland dominated the match with overwhelming possession. Scotland raced ahead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson extended the lead early in the second half. Georgia scored a second try through a powerful scrum won by Lobzhanidze, but Hogg completed a counter-attack for his second try, securing a comprehensive victory for Scotland.

Widnes Vikings beat Castleford Tigers after building a 26-point lead. They survived a late Castleford comeback, which featured a hat-trick from Paddy Flynn, a player on loan from Widnes. The win moved Widnes to seventh in the league, with Castleford staying sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, has been released from the US detention facility at Guantanamo Bay after a review board concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been held there since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. As a condition of his release, he faces at least a year in a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. Mr Odah had argued he travelled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. His release lowers the total number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148.

The song "PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen), performed by fictional character Piko-Taro played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka, became a viral sensation. Known for its simple lyrics, addictive beat, and dance routine, the minute-long video gained over 4 million views on YouTube and more than 44 million on a Facebook post. The song elicited mixed reactions, being both widely enjoyed and considered irritating by some. It has inspired numerous covers and tributes, been compared to Psy's "Gangnam Style," and gained more international popularity than in Japan.

Thousands attended Anzac Day commemorations in London, which included a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, a service at Westminster Abbey, and a parade and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. The day honors the first major World War One battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces, the Gallipoli landings. The events, attended by expatriates, veterans, and service personnel, featured the singing of the Australian and New Zealand national anthems. The tradition of commemorating Anzac Day in London began in 1916, a year after the bloody eight-month Gallipoli campaign, an Allied attempt to force the Ottoman Empire from the war.

Thirty-year-old footballer Clarkson has re-joined St Mirren and is fit and ready for a potential Championship debut against Alloa. Having scored nine goals for Dundee last season, the experienced player, who has two Scotland caps, aims to help St Mirren climb the league table from their eighth position.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, who confirmed that current pension arrangements for workers will be honoured. The new owner plans to restore the company to profitability through greater investment, cost savings, and by using spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

A new Cowes chain ferry has had a troubled start since its May launch, experiencing breakdowns, groundings, suspensions due to training issues, and damage to cars. In response, the council leader has made the crossing free until July 2nd and ordered an auditor's review. Local businesses are suffering from lost trade and are seeking compensation, which a transport councillor said is up for discussion. The council has authorized ramp extensions to fix vehicle damage and a councillor claims electrical problems and seamanship issues have been resolved.

The UK fishing industry, which strongly supported Brexit to escape the EU's Common Fisheries Policy, faces a complex future. While many hope to regain control of UK waters and increase exports, a House of Lords report warns the industry could be marginalized in negotiations due to its small size. The report highlights a key trade-off: to maintain tariff-free access to the EU market for its fish exports, the UK may have to allow EU boats continued access to its waters. This situation is further complicated by shared fish stocks with other EU states and the potential for four different management regimes within the UK. Despite these risks, many in the industry remain optimistic about the opportunities Brexit will bring.

Timothy Geaney, a teacher, admitted to taking or permitting indecent images of children between 2004 and 2014. He received a community payback order and was placed on the sex offenders register. Following a hearing, the General Teaching Council Scotland removed him from the teaching register, concluding his long-term conduct was fundamentally incompatible with the profession and that there was a strong likelihood of reoffending. He was found unfit to teach and barred from re-applying for two years.

A fire on March 2nd at a Duncan Street waste site, operated by Asset and Land Group for Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste and has decided to revoke its environmental permit, effective August 7th subject to appeal. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS), which had raised concerns to the EA prior to the fire, noted the site was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The company must still remove all waste from the site, and the cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria missed a deadline to destroy its chemical weapons, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad blaming attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups" and the ongoing war. The US expressed concern that only 4% of the stockpile has been removed, while Russia set a new transfer deadline of March 1st. Mekdad rejected US condemnation of the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which human rights groups claim have killed hundreds of civilians, including children. The Syrian government and opposition groups provided conflicting reports on the status of Aleppo's central prison, with activists claiming rebels had seized it.

England defeated Pakistan at Old Trafford to level the series, achieving their second-biggest win over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 and 71 not out, and also taking four catches and a wicket. England's captain and coach praised Root's performance, while Pakistan's captain cited poor shot selection and a lack of confidence as reasons for the defeat.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She is gathering experiences from residents, their families, and care staff to develop recommendations for providers and public bodies, aiming to highlight both good and poor care. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, its chair, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that no provider expert was included on the main advisory panel, viewing it as a missed opportunity for partnership.

Former Aberdeen midfielder Paul Sheerin, 39, is replacing Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. He leaves his role as Arbroath's player-manager, a position he held since 2010 where he guided the team to their first national trophy in 2011. Aberdeen manager Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a comprehensive process, and Arbroath's chairman allowed him to join the club.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Swansea's interim managers, Curtis and Paul Williams, will take charge while the club seeks to quickly appoint Paul Clement as its new boss. Curtis, a long-time club figure, fears relegation and the difficulty of returning from the Championship. He believes the club has lost its way and diluted its "Swansea Way" playing style since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, citing frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements. Despite this, he feels the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds players of the club's history to motivate them.

Biologist and entrepreneur Dr. J. Craig Venter revolutionized genomics by developing a faster RNA-based gene sequencing method. This enabled him to sequence the first complete genome of a free-living organism and to found the commercial company Celera Genomics, creating a competitive race to map the human genome. His approach, which disregarded scientific conventions like open data access, drew criticism from the scientific community. After the genome project, Venter founded the J. Craig Venter Institute, which created the first synthetic life form, an organism called Synthia. His sense of urgency, stemming from his service in the Vietnam War, also drives his oceanic project to collect and sequence microbial life.

A Sutton Trust report warns that many English apprenticeships are low quality, too short, and mainly for over-25s already in work, not young people. The study highlights that fewer than 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts are at level three (A-level equivalent) and that England has a complex system of 18,000 vocational qualifications versus Germany's 330. The report calls for creating up to 300,000 new, high-quality apprenticeships per year, with most being at least level three and lasting a minimum of three years. The Department for Education states reforms to raise standards are already underway, while the Association of Colleges agrees on the need for quality but questions the feasibility of the expansion and says some respected lower-level apprenticeships should be preserved.

British Paralympian Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female with 22 medals, began her career in swimming before switching to cycling in 2005. She has won 21 world titles across both sports and is targeting success at the upcoming Rio Games.

Hereford United were expelled from the Football Conference after failing to pay a £148,000 debt to football creditors, despite being granted three deadline extensions by the league. The club, which had total debts of around £225,000 and faced a winding-up petition, was taken over by new owner Tommy Agombar shortly before the final deadline. Their expulsion reverses their dramatic final-day survival, with Chester FC being reinstated to the Conference Premier in their place. The club's financial decline was worsened by significantly falling attendances since its relegation from the Football League in 2012.

Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, is retiring from international football. He won 61 senior caps for England after his 2009 debut, was a squad member for two World Cups and two European Championships, and scored one goal. He also holds the record for England Under-21 caps with 46.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge following a lengthy illness. A highly influential conductor, he was a key figure in the early-music movement and a founder of the historically informed music approach. In 1973, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), which he directed for 30 years, producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood also held artistic and academic posts, including with the King's Lynn Festival, Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and as a professor at Cambridge and Harvard. He is remembered for his generosity, academic mind, and for mentoring many of today's leading musicians.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream schooling as he was not coping, but his family is still waiting for a place in a special school after being told all local facilities are at full capacity. The boy feels isolated and does not understand why he cannot attend school like his siblings. His family now hopes he may start at a local special school soon following the employment of an extra classroom assistant. The boy's mother fears the over-subscribed special needs system will cause similar problems for other families. The Education Authority stated it could not comment on the individual case but is reviewing the need for special school places to ensure future availability.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is making a takeover bid for the Newport Gwent Dragons and views their shared stadium, Rodney Parade, as a rugby venue. Newport County, a football club and co-tenant, holds a lease with primacy of fixtures until 2023 if they remain in the Football League, and they expect this contract to be honoured. A potential conflict exists as the WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of relegation with two games left to play.

A former Sierra Leonean child soldier, who was kidnapped by the RUF and forced to commit atrocities, found purpose through a preacher he met in jail. During the 2014 Ebola crisis, he and his organization, Lifeline Nehemiah, fought the virus by educating communities, providing food support, and establishing a treatment unit. Now regretful of his past, he believes in investing in young people to build the future.

A collection of about 80,000 items from the Wedgwood Museum, which faced being auctioned to pay the pension debt of the collapsed pottery firm Waterford Wedgwood plc, has been saved by a public fundraising campaign. The campaign hit its target within a month, allowing the collection to be gifted by The Art Fund to the Victoria and Albert Museum. The collection will then be loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, where it will remain on display.

Details of a potential deal for Mark Wright to buy a 20% stake in Billericay Town and become a club director have not yet been released. The potential investment follows the club's recent takeover by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week. Billericay, currently eighth in their league and three points from a play-off place, recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright is a 30-year-old former non-league footballer who was runner-up on 'I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here' in 2011.

Following the Brexit referendum, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney announced a one-year extension to his term, a "third way" between leaving in 2018 or staying until 2021. Carney stated the decision was an entirely personal one, not due to political pressure or economic forecasts. The primary reason was his family's plan to return to Canada in 2018 when two of his daughters finish their schooling. The one-year extension allows him to remain in office during the initial Brexit negotiations before his departure, after which a new Governor will take over.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Jamille Matt gave the home side the lead after 12 minutes, but Kurtis Guthrie equalised for Colchester from close range following a corner. Both teams missed chances to win the game, and Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray was shown a straight red card in injury time.

Northern Ireland charity, Action Mental Health, has developed the "Healthy Me" programme for P6 and P7 pupils to help them cope with the stress of transitioning to secondary school and transfer tests. The programme uses interactive workshops to teach children about emotional wellbeing, how to seek help, and relaxation techniques like breathing exercises, while also providing basic training for teachers. After a pilot in five schools, the charity aims to roll out the programme across Northern Ireland. This initiative aligns with the chief inspector of schools' view that strengthening the resilience of young people is a key challenge for the education system.

Developers Fawley Waterside are planning a £1 billion "merchant city" development on the site of the disused Fawley power station, with the 198-metre-high chimney as its centerpiece attraction. The project, which could see building start in 2018, will feature a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and ferry links. The oil-fired power station, commissioned in 1971 and closed in 2013, was capable of powering one million homes. The developers view the chimney as a "signature piece of infrastructure" that can be transformed into a spectacular landmark with relatively little investment.

At the Hong Kong championships, Great Britain's Oliver Latham won a bronze medal in the men's scratch race, the team's second medal following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham finished behind gold medallist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver medallist Lucass Liss of Germany. In other events, the men's team pursuit was beaten for bronze by Italy, and Joe Truman was eliminated in the keirin semi-finals. The women's team pursuit, a young squad with an average age of 19, finished fifth and failed to make the medal race. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was also eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.

Actor Ross Kemp will briefly return to *EastEnders* for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Peggy's character is being killed off after her cancer returns. Kemp's character, Grant Mitchell, will come back to reunite the Mitchell family as they face their mother's death.

Sadio Mane scored twice as second-placed Tottenham lost at Liverpool. Manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire, stating they were not ready to fight for the Premier League and noting it would be a "big problem" if Chelsea extended their lead. The defeat highlights Spurs' poor away form against top-six teams, with only one win in their last 17 such matches, a weakness also pointed out by pundit Danny Murphy, who questioned their defensive tactics and mindset.

In Nigeria's governorship elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared posts, delivering the biggest defeat to the ruling Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The APC's gains in the north and Lagos relegate the PDP to a largely regional party in the south-east. A key challenge for president-elect Muhammadu Buhari is that the APC failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. The elections were marred by some violence but were overall more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP's loss is attributed to a desire for change, corruption allegations, and defections.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) is introducing a new augmented reality app for its event in Stornoway from 19 to 22 July. The app will enable visitors to use phones and tablets to scan items like signs and posters to access online material, including videos and band interviews with acts such as The Waterboys and Imelda May. This feature is designed to enhance the on-site experience and allow a global audience to interact with the festival remotely, with content updated before and during the event to provide information, interviews, and ticket purchasing.

Following Ofsted inspections linked to the "Trojan Horse" affair, several Birmingham schools rated inadequate are facing government action. Funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary will be terminated, while Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School have been warned they will lose funding unless they address concerns such as discrimination, gender segregation, and an unbalanced curriculum. An anonymous head teacher described a campaign of intimidation by parents, and Ofsted's chief reported a "culture of fear and intimidation" and an organised campaign to impose a narrow ideology. The Park View Educational Trust plans to legally challenge the Ofsted report, while some parents have accused inspectors of bias. Saltley School, placed in special measures, will receive a temporary governing board.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years in an Iranian jail for allegedly plotting to topple the government, though the charges were not disclosed. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, believes she is a diplomatic bargaining chip and criticises the UK government. A secret appeal is being held in Tehran. Following her arrest, her two-year-old daughter, Gabriella, has remained in Iran with grandparents and has lost her English. Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe spent time in solitary confinement and felt suicidal, but her condition has since improved. Amnesty International has called her a 'prisoner of conscience' and hopes for her release.

Vincent Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test. Eye specialist Honey Rose is on trial for gross negligence manslaughter, which she denies. The prosecution alleges her failure to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation was so far below the expected standard it was criminal, and that this led to a build-up of fluid in his brain and his death. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity with a man he found online and filming the encounters. He was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images by sending an explicit clip. Following a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court, the case was sent to the High Court for sentencing due to its greater powers. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register, and a judge stated the sentence must reflect "society's abhorrence" at his conduct. He was assessed as a first offender who poses a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Afghanistan defeated Ireland by six wickets. Ireland scored 165-5, with Stuart Thompson making 56, Gary Wilson scoring 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield adding 39. Afghanistan successfully chased the target, reaching 171-4 with two overs to spare, led by Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Porterfield reflected that Ireland fell short with both bat and ball, and the teams will meet again for a second T20 on Friday.

Barcelona's signing of Neymar is under investigation by Spanish authorities over the true cost of the transfer and alleged tax discrepancies. While the club initially stated the fee was £48.6m, the total cost is alleged to be £106.8m. Following the accusations, Barcelona's president, Sandro Rosell, resigned, and a judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue the investigation. Barcelona has made a complimentary tax payment of €13.55 million but denies any tax-related crime, stating the payment is to cover potential divergent interpretations of the contracts and defend the club's reputation.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao. Two Burmese migrant workers are being held as suspects by Thai police. UK Metropolitan Police detectives have completed their review of the investigation in Thailand and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families. The suspects, who allegedly confessed, face charges of murder, rape, and robbery, with Thai police stating DNA evidence links them to the crime. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the Thai investigation, specifically regarding DNA verification and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects.

Virtual reality (VR) is being used as a tool in journalism, healthcare, retail, and education. For public awareness, the UK's National Autistic Society created a VR film about living with autism, and Alzheimer's Research UK released one showing the challenges of dementia. In healthcare, VR is used to train doctors via live-streamed surgeries and to treat conditions such as PTSD and arachnophobia. Retailers like Ikea use VR to help customers visualise products, as seen with a popular virtual kitchen app. In education, VR facilitates virtual field trips and language learning, with potential to increase student engagement, though the cost of hardware is a significant hurdle for schools.

The black box of a Russian Su-24 jet, downed by Turkey, was opened in Moscow, but key flight data appears to be missing. The data was intended to resolve the dispute over the jet's location when it was hit, with Turkey claiming it ignored warnings to leave its airspace and Russia insisting it was shot down in Syria. The incident caused a diplomatic crisis, leading Russia to impose sanctions, including a ban on package holidays, and demand an apology. The pilot and a Russian marine sent to rescue the crew were killed.

The Scottish women's football team, having won all five qualifiers, faces a crucial match against unbeaten Iceland that will likely decide their group and determine who qualifies for the finals in the Netherlands. A victory would secure their place and avoid the "heartbreak" of previous play-off losses. Forward Claire Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, highlights the team's determination and the benefit of having 12 of the 20 squad members playing in top leagues abroad, which she believes adds to the national team's strength.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform, set up by the Scottish government, found there is no easy solution to fix the council tax system's defects. The review by Prof. Kenneth Gibb noted that while property tax is stable and widely used, many find it unfair because it is not linked to income. Alternatively, a local income tax is perceived as fairer but creates financial instability for local authorities. The Scottish government considers the current council tax unfair and awaits the commission's report, which is due in the autumn following a public consultation.

Following the theft of celebrity photos using third-party software, Apple extended its two-step verification to iCloud backups. The system now requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device when accessing an account from new hardware, with a 14-character recovery key as an alternative. The creator of the hacking tool confirmed the update is secure and his software no longer works. Despite this, the feature is an opt-in choice, and experts have raised concerns that the difficult-to-remember recovery key could lead to users being permanently locked out if lost. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable the feature.

In the May European Parliament election, the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 and the winning party, UKIP, spent £2,956,737. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339, while the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575. The cost per vote was 79p for the Conservatives, 68p for UKIP, 26p for Labour, and £1.45 for the Lib Dems. The Green Party spent £534,249. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 election.

National League club The Gulls have signed two players: 27-year-old centre-back Anderson and 21-year-old striker Keating. Anderson has cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their rivals, while Keating, who was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, is moving subject to international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as the leader-type he was after and Keating as young, raw, and hungry. The signings come as the Gulls are four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," an incident described as rare and occurring in horses without underlying health issues. Although the horse had a previous history of post-race ataxia and overheating, he showed no such symptoms on the day of his death. The report concludes he was the victim of a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack. The horse, a previous Grand National and Hennessy Gold Cup winner, was described by his trainer as the "horse of a lifetime".

Several veteran MSPs, including former First Minister Alex Salmond, Labour's Duncan McNeil, and Conservative Annabel Goldie, gave farewell speeches as they stand down ahead of the May 5th election. In his address, Mr. Salmond stated Scotland is "diverse, not divided" and criticized the Scotland Bill for not delivering sufficient powers. Mr. McNeil warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability. The Presiding Officer, Tricia Marwick, was visibly moved by the speeches.

Emma Watson will star as Belle in a new film adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, directed by Bill Condon. The cast includes Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Kevin Kline as Maurice. An unnamed star has also been cast as Mrs. Potts. The film is scheduled for release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, and begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision on potential charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 fans were unlawfully killed. The CPS has reviewed evidence against 23 suspects: 15 investigated for the disaster's causes and 8 for a subsequent police conduct investigation. Victims' relatives will be informed of the decision at a private meeting as they long continue to seek accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has reported "numerous incidents" of packages being hurled over its walls, a claim supported by a local resident who witnessed it multiple times. A former inmate stated the jail is "flooded" with contraband like mobile phones and synthetic cannabis and claimed drones were used, but the Ministry of Justice said there is no evidence of drones at the site. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged that more must be done to stop contraband, noting that the Justice Secretary has asked for a review of how to tackle the problem. New laws mean people who smuggle packages over prison walls could be jailed for up to two years. The prison is also holding meetings with local residents to discuss the issue.

Brian Wright, 55, struck Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, with his car outside a school last December, causing serious head injuries. Wright, whose trial is ongoing, claims he was blinded by the sun, while the prosecution alleges he ran a red light. He admits to hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving and has apologized in court. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care.

Middle-distance runner Muir will miss the Commonwealth Games to focus on her final year of veterinary medicine studies and upcoming exams. She recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best in the 5000m. While "gutted" to miss the event, she prioritizes completing her degree. Muir is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March and believes she has at least two more Olympics in her future.

A search involving excavations has begun at a three-acre site in Chapelizod, Dublin, for Trevor Deely, who was 22 when he disappeared in December 2000. The search, expected to last several weeks, follows a review of his case. Enhanced CCTV footage from the night he went missing shows Mr. Deely talking to and being followed by an unidentified man in black. Gardaí have renewed an appeal for this man to come forward as he has not yet been identified.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after more than two years with injury problems, defeated Stan Wawrinka in a four-set victory. This is the former world number four's first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open following three wrist operations. Del Potro, who is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray, will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. In other matches, 15th seed Nick Kyrgios came from behind to beat Dustin Brown in a rain-affected game and is on course to meet Murray in the last 16. Kyrgios's next opponent is Feliciano Lopez, who also won after a comeback victory over Fabio Fognini. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also secured routine victories.

Tunisia and Morocco faced potential exclusion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was threatened with expulsion after lodging complaints to CAF about a contentious penalty during their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea, a dispute resolved after Tunisia issued an apology. Morocco was banned by CAF for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced a significant fine. Following these resolutions, both teams are now included in the 2017 qualifying draw.

The McLaren Formula 1 team, a historically dominant force with 182 wins, 12 drivers' titles, and eight constructors' titles, is currently in a significant slump. Despite having two world champion drivers, their results are focused on minor points and low grid positions. The team's history is described as a cycle of triumph and decline, including a dominant era with Honda in the late 1980s featuring Senna and Prost. The current downturn, which began in 2013, is blamed on an underperforming Honda power-unit, contrary to their past successful partnership with the manufacturer. The team has also been marred by past scandals like 'spygate' in 2007 and 'lie-gate' in 2009. However, team boss Ron Dennis is confident that McLaren will arrest this slide and return to winning ways, a belief that prompted Fernando Alonso to join the team in 2015.

Following a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, police found people still there and evidence that alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST on 6 October 2014. At Limavady Magistrates Court, the license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge closed the bar for three months, fined O'Neill £3,000 for her "appalling record," and fined Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. In another game, the Chicago Bulls rallied from a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89-78, outscoring Miami 57-27 in the second half.

YouTube star and free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen met Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at their training ground. The players were initially led to believe he was a competition winner, but Van Velzen surprised them by showcasing his exceptional dead-ball skills. He enjoyed the experience, particularly pretending he was not a skilled player to see their reactions, and concluded with a surprise for Balotelli related to his infamous slogan.

A study of 676 women with breast cancer and BRCA gene mutations found that removing the ovaries (oophorectomy) significantly reduces the risk of death for BRCA1 carriers. The procedure was associated with a 62% decrease in breast cancer deaths and a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The benefit was even greater—a 73% reduction in death—when performed within two years of diagnosis, with the protective effect lasting 15 years. This significant reduction in breast cancer mortality was not observed in women with the BRCA2 mutation. Researchers suggest that oophorectomy should be discussed as a treatment option for BRCA1 carriers at the time of diagnosis.

On Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina, a married couple, 38-year-old Derek Lowe and 33-year-old Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train they were lingering on. The train, No. 80 traveling from Charlotte to New York City, was delayed for nearly three hours, though none of its 166 passengers were injured. A witness suggested the couple may have been homeless and were struggling to cross the tracks with a cart.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member, worked as a DEA informant for 27 years with the promise of U.S. citizenship. He became a crucial asset, aiding in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. After retiring due to health issues, Toro was never granted citizenship, his visa expired, and he now faces deportation to Colombia, where he fears for his life. The DEA has refused to help him secure his status.

A Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., is using the new '.sucks' domain to extract large sums, around $2,499 a year, from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube and Visa to protect their reputations. This practice has been called a "predatory shakedown scheme" by an advisory panel. The US internet regulator, ICANN, has asked US and Canadian authorities to investigate if the company's actions are illegal.

27 years after a baby boy's body was found in a Norfolk pond, his mother was identified through DNA evidence. Following a case review, police exhumed the body and matched a DNA sample to a relative, which led them to the mother. The mother, who had concealed her pregnancy, stated the baby was stillborn. Police accepted her account, ruled out foul play, and dropped the initial suspicion of infanticide. The baby, originally buried as an unknown, was reburied and named Peter, and his mother remains on bail while prosecutors consider lesser charges.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to his passenger, Kristopher Hicks. After mistakenly believing Hicks planned to flee without paying, Young unlawfully imprisoned him by driving him away from his destination. Hicks jumped from the moving taxi, suffering severe brain injuries, epilepsy, and now requires constant care. A High Court judge ruled in Hicks's favor, awarding him damages, though the final amount of compensation is yet to be decided and will be reduced from the family's initial claim.

Severe storms with tornadoes hit Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night. In Kansas, a tornado was reported near Goddard and other sightings occurred in the southwestern part of the state. In Missouri, a potential tornado caused wind damage and flooding in Potosi, and baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. An expert warned of the danger of nighttime tornadoes, and the weather service forecasted more storms for the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Middleweights Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to fight in New Jersey, with the winner expected to earn a title shot. Rockhold, seeking his fourth consecutive win, plans to be the aggressive "bull" to Machida's "matador," asserting he has found weaknesses in Machida's game and holds advantages in speed and skill. Machida, also coming off a victory, is confident he can win by applying his own style and technique, feeling well-prepared after an eight-week training camp. Rockhold believes Machida has a small chance of winning, while Machida has identified a couple of weaknesses in Rockhold but needs to be in the fight to exploit them.

An 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, landed his Aerostar plane in Fort Pierce, Florida, without its landing gear deployed. The aircraft skidded on its belly, damaging the propellers upon impact with the runway. After realizing his mistake, the pilot took off again and managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini has admitted disappointment in Yaya Touré's performance this season but vowed to support him until the end of the season. Despite this, Manchester City will listen to offers for the midfielder as they look to overhaul their ageing squad after a poor run of form, having taken just 18 points from the last 39 available. Goalkeeper Joe Hart said the players have let the manager down, though Pellegrini accepted responsibility for selecting the team. Separately, Manchester City are interested in West Ham left-back Aaron Cresswell, a player his manager Sam Allardyce has warned not to join a big club where he might not play, citing the examples of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive living in the UK for over 20 years, will be allowed to remain in the country after his extradition sentence was dropped. He had lost a battle against being sent to Italy to serve a seven-year sentence for mafia association. However, his sentence was extinguished under Italian law because a period of more than double the penalty time had passed. A delay caused by the Crown Prosecution Service's failure to appeal a decision on time contributed to the sentence expiring. His European arrest warrant is now to be withdrawn, and he will be formally discharged by a UK court, although the case still requires a hearing by the Italian supreme court.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is a 7-2 co-favorite for the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race before retiring. The other co-favorites are Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville. McCoy announced his retirement after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February.

Forty years after her daughter Marcia was raped and murdered in 1975, Virginia Trimble Ritter recently viewed crime scene photos she had long avoided. Ritter, who had been advised by her husband not to see the photos, described the horrific state of her daughter's body and said she now wants revenge. The murder, committed by Jerome Sydney Barrett, went unsolved for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence linked him to the crime. He was convicted in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy considers it "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters to complete the career Grand Slam, which would make him only the sixth player in history to achieve the feat. He credits his final-round collapse at the 2011 Masters as the "most important day of my career," stating the painful loss taught him lessons that led to his first major win at the US Open two months later. Despite recent distractions from calling off his wedding and a costly legal dispute, McIlroy views the golf course as a "sanctuary" from pressure and plans to focus on playing his best rather than the surrounding hype.

The passage summarizes a week's collection of trending stories. Key events included the appearance of four rainbows over New York and China's crackdown on hiring exotic dancers for wakes. In entertainment news, Robert Downey Jr. ended an interview after becoming agitated, Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', and Johnny Depp appeared nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer. Viral trends involved the dangerous #kyliejennerchallenge for lip plumping and a school's rejection of a bomb-themed prom-posal. Other stories featured a 102-year-old woman revisiting her past, a military dad photobombing his son, and a pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."

Last year, 272 children in England were hospitalized with disabilities from Foetal Alcohol Syndrome caused by prenatal alcohol exposure. Experts believe this is an underestimation, with WHO research suggesting 1 in 100 UK babies (around 7,500 annually) suffer from related learning, behavioural and physical problems. The condition is permanent, leads to severe lifelong disabilities, and is often undiagnosed. Although government guidance permits minimal alcohol consumption during pregnancy, experts advocate for a policy of total abstinence.

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, attempted to rob the Shildon Post Office and Stores but was tackled by the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon. Dhillon's wife, Sam, then struck McKerry with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him before police arrived and arrested him. McKerry, who had a long criminal history and was nicknamed 'boomerang boy' for always returning home after crimes, pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party in a Nova Scotia barracks. Following a court appearance, they were granted bail on the condition they remain in Nova Scotia, live on a Canadian naval base, surrender their passports, and continue their employment with the Royal Navy until their trial. The alleged assault occurred after a hockey game, and the charges are punishable by up to 14 years in prison.

Four-year-old RJ Jackson has Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare disease affecting approximately 70 people worldwide, which makes his skin appear red, inflamed, and scalded. Due to his condition, his mother, Valerie Jackson, was reported to the police by a stranger in a Las Vegas Walmart who suspected child abuse. The family also faces regular public taunts, stares, and has been denied entry to a playhouse. The painful illness requires constant care, including moisturizing his skin every few hours. After RJ's birth, his mother struggled for a diagnosis until she found a Facebook group for the syndrome, which helped her identify the condition. She believes the public reaction is a result of ignorance and hopes for greater awareness.

Campaigners are celebrating as Protein World's controversial "Are you beach body ready?" adverts are being removed from the London Underground. Transport for London (TfL) stated the removal is because the paid three-week advertising period has ended, but it acknowledged the strong customer reaction. The adverts, featuring a bikini-clad model, caused a significant backlash, resulting in a petition with over 50,000 signatures, more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA), and vandalism. Protein World defended its campaign, claiming it was meant to promote health, but the company also received threats, including a bomb threat. The ASA is currently assessing the complaints.

Rail firms are planning fare hikes of up to 87% shortly after a general election where main party leaders pledged to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has intervened, asking First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review its planned 87% increase on its London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his constituency. Other companies, including Virgin Trains and London Midlands, are also implementing significant price increases. The firms have defended the changes, with FGW stating it is aligning route pricing and Virgin noting the hikes are on cheaper, company-specific fares and that its overall increase is below the industry average.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, has been blinded in his left eye after being struck in the face by a brick. The attack occurred when he confronted thugs who were throwing stones at his home in Oldham. The incident, which happened just three weeks after his wedding, has left him with a permanent disability and feeling unsafe in his home. Police have launched an investigation but stated there appears to be no motive, suspecting it may have been yobs "messing around."

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a one-year contract extension, keeping him with the county until the end of 2016. The contract rewards his successful return from leg injuries sustained in a road accident which caused him to miss the 2014 season and in which his father died. He has made his playing comeback and will be available for the start of the season.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw has been declared cancer-free after a year of treatment for neuroblastoma, an aggressive cancer that had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. To help him feel brave during radiotherapy, he decorated his protective mask like a Ninja Turtle, a story that gained public attention and awards for his bravery. He will continue to have regular check-ups.

Aston Villa's 19-year-old player Jack Grealish is the subject of an international tug-of-war between the Republic of Ireland and England. His manager, Tim Sherwood, and his father both advise him to concentrate on his club career with Aston Villa before making a decision. Sherwood states the choice is Grealish's to make with his heart, and the player is expected to decide at the end of the season. Grealish, who has previously played for Ireland's youth teams, is currently split on the matter.

Landing fees for private jets, a significant cost for wealthy travelers, vary dramatically between airports and are highest during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix. The three most expensive airports to land a 767-400 jet are all in Japan: Haneda in Tokyo at £4,559 ($6,850), Narita in Tokyo at £3,728 ($5,600), and Kansai in Osaka at £3,594 ($5,400). The top 10 also includes airports in Toronto, Darwin, Bristol, Dublin, New York, and Salzburg.

A video of a Labrador named Cooper eating an entire ice cream cone in one bite has been viewed over seven million times. His owner, Katie Gallegos, took Cooper and another dog, Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for the treat. While Daisy licks her ice cream slowly, Cooper gobbles his whole cone, which his owner states is his normal eating behavior. The video received some criticism from viewers concerned about feeding dogs ice cream, but Gallegos defended the occasional treat, citing her previous dog lived to 19 with a similar diet. The passage also notes the dogs enjoy whipped cream "pup-uccinos" from Starbucks.

Gary Locke has been appointed the permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year deal. He initially joined as an assistant manager but took over as interim in February when Allan Johnston quit. His permanent appointment follows a successful interim period where the team lost only one of seven games.

Jessica Kemp, a Florida mother, accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son because of the essential oils she applies to him to help him stay calm and focused. The school claimed the scents were a distraction to other students and staff. Although Kemp planned to fight the decision, the local school district later stated the boy would not be suspended, classifying the matter as a "health issue."
