The Sandpiper, a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach used as a holiday home, was destroyed by fire on Wednesday at 3 PM. The blaze engulfed 90 condos, causing the building to collapse. The fire was so intense it melted paint on nearby buildings and was visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews responded but were unable to enter the structure. The cause of the fire is unknown and under investigation, though one claim suggests it started near a parked car. The building manager, who lived on-site, lost everything in the fire.

Approaching her 89th birthday, the Queen was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, without a helmet, a choice she has attributed to her hair. A lifelong equestrian who now rides less due to a knee injury, she continues to breed Fell and Highland ponies. The Fell pony is an ancient, hardy breed from Cumbria, historically used as a pack animal and later becoming a popular riding horse for families.

A dispute over noise between two Brisbane neighbours resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman. His neighbour, 28-year-old Phillip Pama, has been charged with manslaughter for allegedly killing Yeaman with a single punch. The incident occurred when Pama, a shift worker trying to sleep, confronted Yeaman for making a loud commotion. Pama's defence stated the situation escalated and he threw a "blind" punch while being pushed. Pama, who has no history of violence, was granted conditional bail.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship for a classmate. During a police sting operation, she offered 100,000 rubles and gave specific instructions for the torture to an undercover officer. Simonova was arrested immediately after the meeting, was charged with attempted murder, and now faces 15 years in prison. Her former pupil, Vanya, said he was relieved by her arrest.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho states he talks to God every day but never about football, only praying for personal matters. He tries to separate his professional and family life, never discussing the game with his wife. Despite his arrogant professional persona, he claims to be a good person, family man, and friend, acknowledging he makes mistakes in his career. He and his family also work as ambassadors against hunger with the World Food Programme.

At 91 years old, Bob Barker, the former host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show for the first time in eight years. He hosted the first game of an April 1st episode before handing the duties back to current host Drew Carey.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. early Friday morning for allegedly attempting to break into a house and destroying property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. This incident follows another case of misconduct against a high-ranking supervisor and adds to recent scrutiny of the agency, which is already investigating a separate incident involving two officials.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, left his car at a safari park and crept to within 10 feet of a hungry lion to photograph it. After lying on the ground and capturing a few frames, the camera's shutter sound alerted the lion, which then aggressively jumped towards him. Saeed was forced to retreat rapidly to the safety of his car, later calling it a close encounter he would not repeat.

New York City police have released an image of a distinctive tattoo to help identify a woman who died in Brooklyn on March 22. The unnamed victim, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, had no identification on her. The tattoo on her right leg is a heart with a rose and the name "Monique." The cause of death is pending a medical examiner's report, and police are asking anyone with information to come forward.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom, solar-powered home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck. After returning from the UK, they undertook the year-and-a-half project because they could not afford to buy property. The resulting $25,000 wood and steel home, located on their lot in Nelson, allows them to live nearly self-sufficiently with power from solar panels, water from a nearby spring, and gas for the stove and hot water.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, involving 352 kindergarten students, found that those who shared iPads scored about 30 points higher on early literacy tests than their peers with no iPads or one-to-one devices. The researcher attributes the improvement to the "collaborative learning around the technology."

A piglet in China, born without back legs, has learned to walk on its two front trotters. The animal, nicknamed "super pig," belongs to farmer Ms. Duan in Qionglai city and became an internet sensation after a video of it balancing and foraging for food was posted online. The piglet mixes with its litter and has attracted many villagers. The passage also notes a two-legged rabbit at a Chinese zoo that became a similar attraction.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Dale Coyne Racing pit crew member Todd Phillips was injured when struck by the car of driver Francesco Dracone. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center, received stitches for a cut, and was released. Dracone did not finish the race, and many cars struggled with traction due to rain before the event.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times, an act captured on CCTV. The attack occurred at their apartment in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, four days after they were married. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating he was jealous of men looking at her. After the murder, he stole a neighbor's car, crashed it during his getaway, and was arrested. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his possession, and he now faces life in jail.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, known for her book "I Quit Sugar," revealed that severe anxiety drove her to contemplate suicide. She attributed this to a mix of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation. Wilson, who has now found some peace, believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this connection is crucial to address the rising rates of anxiety among Australian women, which she calls the "new depression."

Prosecutors dropped second-degree assault charges against Elena Curtin, a pregnant Oregon woman, after she struck her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. Curtin found the woman shooting heroin in her bathroom and attacked her when she refused to leave. The charge was dismissed because prosecutors found Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage" under Oregon law, which allows for the use of physical force against an intruder.

A pit bull named Gemma, who lives with two children in California, was tricked by her owner into eating a piece of broccoli. Upon eating it, Gemma looked disgusted and spat the vegetable on the floor. The passage notes this is a bad example for the children and adds that Gemma also enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website mistakenly directed visitors to a pornographic page. The error occurred because the address was for the now-defunct young entrepreneur awards, which had been discontinued in 2011, allowing a porn site to take over the expired registration. HSBC removed the link, issued a public apology, and denied any association with the external site, while confirming its own website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy called 911 and calmly provided instructions to firefighters, leading to the rescue of himself and his 9-year-old sister who were trapped in a second-floor bedroom during a house fire. During the 11-minute call, he also comforted his sister. Firefighters rescued the children by breaking a window, and they were taken to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The other three family members escaped on their own and were taken to a different hospital.

Amazing pictures show blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast at Jervis Bay, NSW. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the neon glow, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton. According to oceanography expert Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, the glow is caused by a single-celled phytoplankton called *Noctiluca scintillans*. This carnivorous cell, which blossoms in spring and autumn due to natural causes, preys on diatoms and emits light as a defense mechanism. Suthers stated there is no need to be concerned, as a similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.

New tests can pinpoint genetic markers in breast cancer tumors to determine their aggressiveness and risk of recurrence after surgery. For some women, these tests can show a recurrence risk as low as five per cent, allowing them to potentially avoid chemotherapy, a treatment with severe side effects including hair loss, nausea, and fatigue. One such test, endopredict, is currently available privately for about £2,500, but specialists hope it will be offered on the NHS, arguing the cost is offset by savings from not administering unnecessary chemotherapy. Experts believe these tests enable patients to make an informed choice about their treatment.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over a nine-year period, while 99 servicewomen were sent home from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq for the same reason between 2006 and 2013. Military regulations prohibit pregnant women from serving on ships or in war zones, necessitating their removal. A strict "no touching" rule on Navy ships at sea suggests most pregnancies were conceived before deployment or during leave. The text also cites the case of Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, who was removed from her command following claims of an inappropriate relationship with a crew member.

A drone carrying traces of a radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese prime minister's residence in Tokyo. The unmanned vehicle was also equipped with a camera and smoke flares. The incident has raised concerns about potential drone terrorism, with officials citing threats to future events like the Olympics and the G7 summit. The discovery coincided with a court's approval to restart two nuclear reactors, a move unpopular with many Japanese following the Fukushima disaster.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on his motorbike. He began this after his father's death because he feared she would get home alone, as his wife works in another city and his son is in school. For the one-hour journey, he ties a sash around both of them for safety. His employer, a bank, provides a room for his mother, and he checks on her during the day, feeling it is his duty to care for her in return for her devotion.

A major study found that heavy and binge drinking increased among Americans between 2005 and 2012, with heavy drinking rising by 17.2 percent. This increase was largely driven by women, whose binge-drinking rates grew more than seven times the rate among men. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. The study attributes the trend to changing social norms for women, the increasing affordability of alcohol, a rise in alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies.

UN officials from the WHO warn that doctors are performing Caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and babies at risk of short- and long-term health problems, including infections and death. The procedure should only be done when medically necessary, but in England over a quarter of births are by C-section, a rate that has more than doubled since the 1990s. The WHO advises an ideal rate of 10-15%, which contradicts NHS guidelines that allow C-sections for non-medical reasons such as maternal anxiety.

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a Martha's Vineyard home, living there for at least a week, and selling the owner's belongings in a yard sale. The homeowner discovered her inside the Edgartown property, and she was later apprehended when she returned. Filkins has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Police are asking anyone who purchased items, including furniture and a painting, to return them.

After a lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke was handed in to Albury police, officers discovered it was unlocked. They used her Facebook page to post a series of humorous selfies and photos of the phone, including placing it in a holding cell. The posts, which contained puns about the phone being "charged" and in a "cell," were shared by her friends. When Bella arrived at the station to collect her phone, the officers recognized her from her profile photo. She found the situation amusing and has since added a password to her phone.

In South Africa's Isimangaliso Wetland Park, a five-day-old hippo calf was killed after it got caught in a fight between two adult males. The calf was grabbed by one of the hippos, thrown into the air, and dragged along the water's surface while its mother watched. The baby died of its injuries several hours later.

A three-bedroom, unmodernised apartment in the expensive Knightsbridge area of London is for sale for £575,000 but comes with only three years remaining on its lease. The cost over this period is equivalent to the local rental rate for a similar property. If a buyer extends the lease, which could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year term, the 1,990 sq/ft property could be worth upwards of £6 million. A second, larger maisonette with the same short lease is also available for £595,000.

A computer outage on Friday affected 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada, disabling registers and preventing sales. In response, baristas gave away free drinks and baked goods, which many customers celebrated on social media, while some stores closed early to avoid giving away products. Starbucks stated the outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and announced it was resolved by Friday night, with stores expected to open for business as usual on Saturday. This incident occurred a day after the company posted record quarterly earnings.

According to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, terrorists are undergoing training and are being radicalised in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. Detective Constable Gareth Jones stated that those involved take part in seemingly ordinary community activities but have an ulterior motive. The passage notes incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales dating back to 1998, including the claimed use of the Brecon Beacons for training. It also mentions that two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed in North Wales, a plot for a Mumbai-style attack involved secret meetings in a Welsh country park, and Lee Rigby's murderer, Michael Adebowale, studied at a former institute in Wales. DC Jones stressed that community intelligence is vital for authorities to address these issues, which are not confined to large cities.

An Omura's whale, a rare species feared to be extinct, was discovered washed ashore on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia. This is the first sighting in the state and only the second in Australia, making it a highly significant find for scientists who know little about the species, which was first described in 2003. The 5.68-meter juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling. Typically found in Indonesian, Philippine, and Japanese waters, the whale is characterized by a sleek body and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried so its skeleton can be recovered later for scientific study and possible public display.

A Texas businesswoman argues a woman should not be president, claiming her hormones could make her irrational and start a war. The author counters this by noting male leaders have also made poor decisions and that studies show women take fewer risks. The passage argues the real issue is not hormones but pervasive gender bias against women in leadership, citing evidence like the overrepresentation of men named John, Robert, William, or James on corporate boards versus all women, and the tendency to describe male professors as "geniuses" and female professors as "nice." The author concludes this bias harms everyone, as equality benefits the economy, families, and businesses.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his collection of over 200 antiques, valued at £100,000, as he downsizes his home. A keen military historian and longbow expert, Hardy is auctioning items he has collected over his career, including a 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a yew longbow, furniture, and historical books. The 238-lot auction is being held by Dominic Winter auctioneers in Gloucestershire, and Hardy expressed sadness at selling his treasured collection.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a fugitive suspect in the murder of his 57-year-old mother, Sandra, whose body was found in their Winter Garden, Florida home. He became a suspect after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was discovered. Shemansky, who is on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness and a prior suicide attempt, was reportedly stressed by divorce proceedings. Neighbors suggest his mother may have prevented him from attending the visit, and that receiving bad legal documents may have triggered him. Authorities have the murder weapon and are searching for Shemansky, who was last seen fleeing on foot without medication or provisions.

Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations Council bypassed the usual bidding process, citing a unique strategic opportunity to host the event for the first time in the USA and access a key market. This came after Eugene previously lost its bid for the 2019 event to Doha.

Leonie Granger, 25, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger, an aspiring model, lured Hassan from a London casino to his Islington flat, where she left the door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and his accomplice, Nicholas Chandler. The two men then tied up and kicked Hassan to death to steal his winnings. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and jailed for life with a minimum term of 36 years. All three defendants were also found guilty of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas is experiencing a significant dip in form during the second half of the season, a trend previously noted by his former club, Barcelona. After a brilliant start where he was on track to break the Premier League assist record, his performance has declined sharply, exemplified by a poor game for Spain and a significant drop in assists. This slump, attributed to fatigue from a long season, is a concern for manager Jose Mourinho as Chelsea compete for the title, though a recent assist provides hope for a resurgence.

West Ham are discussing a deal for 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford after he impressed on trial with the club's academy. The club has also announced that season tickets for their new 54,000-capacity Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the cheapest price in the Premier League for the 2016-17 season.

Wiltshire police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on huntsman Mike Lane, despite being provided with a video of the incident and a dossier of evidence. The 40-year-old victim was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars, resulting in concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Police stated the case was stopped due to insufficient evidence, a decision Mr. Lane condemned as 'pathetic'. The case has been recorded as undetected but will be re-opened if further evidence comes to light.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen and al-Qaeda propagandist known as Azzam the American, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Although not a top leader, he was a prominent member who served as the group's chief English-language spokesman, appearing in numerous videos to threaten attacks on the West and urge Muslims to conduct lone-wolf attacks. Born in California, he converted to Islam, moved to Pakistan in 1998 to join al-Qaeda, and was indicted for treason and material support to the organization.

A five-year-old Chinese boy, Mai Zizhuo, has become a viral sensation for his advanced basketball skills, showcased in a video. The footage shows him scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously, abilities he has developed since starting to play at two and a half years old. His talent has won him a large fanbase across China, with netizens reacting with amazement, disbelief, and curiosity about his father.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), a group that campaigned to legalize child sex, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. He attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state regulation of the press. Hacked Off, formed after the phone-hacking scandal, wants a statutory press regulatory body as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's support is an embarrassment to the group, especially given his history as a key PIE activist who was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals'. PIE had previously allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), on which O'Carroll served, to lower the age of consent to ten and legalize incest. O'Carroll confirmed his attendance in a blog, and a Hacked Off spokesman said the meeting was open to the public.

For Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, the Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained to serve as a catwalk for the Ten Pieces fashion label. The label, headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, presented a monochrome, unisex collection of ten items designed to be worn in 20 ways. Models walked through the empty pool against an ocean backdrop for guests and beachgoers on an unseasonably warm day, displacing the club's regular lap swimmers.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in Northern California with his wife and daughter, where he fed a white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions. The 28-year-old also announced earlier that week that his next fight will be against former world champion Chris Algieri on May 30.

The name of Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian beaten and burned alive by three Israelis, was added to an Israeli memorial wall for fallen soldiers and terror victims. His family and Almagor, an organization for Israeli terror victims, objected to his inclusion. The father refused permission and did not want his son listed with Israeli soldiers, while Almagor argued the teen's death was a rogue attack, not an act of terrorism. Following their complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial, announced it will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the wall and its website.

A young boy, filmed by his father in California, repeatedly tried to use his family cat as a pillow in the garden. Each time the boy laid on the cat, it would move to another spot. After several attempts, the cat went indoors. A later video showed the pair made up, with the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a federal police corruption trial in Philadelphia, lost his varsity coaching job after testifying about his past as a marijuana dealer. He alleged that six officers on trial stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest, an incident the private academy that employed him was unaware of because the charges were later expunged. The six former officers are charged with racketeering, extortion, and robbery, and their defense attorneys argue the government's case is based on the testimony of 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop. Kushner also acknowledged a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, sparked a large fire and injured six people. The blast, caused by an oil leak, was battled by over 600 firefighters and is now under control. The plant, which has a history of explosions and was relocated in 2007 due to public protest over pollution concerns, produces a chemical that has sparked demonstrations across China.

Aston Villa teenager Jack Grealish states he will not listen to referees who tell him to pull his socks up, citing a lifelong superstition. He wears his socks low over children's shinpads and has no intention of changing. Grealish, an Ireland under-21 international, recently made his first Premier League start for Villa in a 3-3 draw against QPR, and while pleased with the opportunity, he was unhappy with the match's result.

Bobbi Kristina Brown has "global and irreversible brain damage," is unresponsive, and has a tracheostomy, according to her grandmother and a source. However, her father, Bobby Brown, stated his daughter is awake and watching him. The family's attorney confirmed her condition has improved and she has started a long rehabilitation, but the quality of her life is unknown, although doctors have indicated she will have a long life.

Russia has a 2-0 lead over Germany in their Fed Cup tie, putting them on the brink of the final. Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets, and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova followed by defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets, 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, after saving a match point. Russia now needs just one win from the three remaining matches on Sunday to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for another storm predicted to hit later this week, potentially as an east coast low with heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned more bad weather will hamper clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 jobs from 24,196 requests from the last storm still outstanding. The Hunter region, which suffered severe damage and flooding, is a particular focus for concern due to saturated ground that could easily flood again. Meteorologists suggest the new weather system will be different from the last, moving faster and potentially impacting the state's north-east coast more than Sydney.

Model Nina Moric denied Italian media reports and a statement from her boyfriend that she had attempted suicide. Posting on Instagram, she stated she was hospitalized after a domestic accident, having fallen and hit her head due to low blood pressure. She added she was shocked by the claims but was recovering at home.

A YouGov poll revealed that the British public's favorite name for Kate and William's second child, if it is a girl, is Diana, in honor of William's mother. For a boy, the preferred name is James. The poll of 2,200 people also showed that a quarter of those surveyed hope for a girl, a sentiment echoed on social media. Additionally, the poll found that the majority of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber in Khost, Afghanistan, killed 17 people and wounded 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack targeted protesters on their way to a rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban has denied responsibility for the bombing, and no other group has claimed it.

Dani Alves, a 31-year-old Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed the negotiations were over, stating the offer was a three-year extension dependent on Alves playing in 60% of matches. During his seven successful years at the club, he won four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice.

Pablo Osvaldo, a Boca Juniors player on loan from Southampton, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join the Argentinian club. He believes their abilities and South American style would make them a perfect fit, and that the fans would be thrilled.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson had a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse at Wincanton, which became a viral internet sensation. He was largely unhurt with only a cut on his nose and was back working the next day. Ferguson is undeterred from racing and considers himself lucky.

To coincide with the release of the movie *Avengers: Age of Ultron*, London Wasps captain and England flanker James Haskell posted an Instagram photo of himself in an Iron Man costume. The text then details his career, which began at Wasps in 2002. After leaving in 2009, he played rugby for clubs in France, Japan, and New Zealand before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since rejoining, he has made over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England.

The wide-leg trouser is a key SS15 trend, presented as an effortless alternative to the skinny jean. For a flattering look, high heels are essential to elongate the leg, and the outfit should be paired with a simple top like a knit or shirt to maintain proportion. Denim is considered the easiest way to adopt the trend, which was featured on the runways of designers like Gucci and Celine, with high-street versions such as the Topshop Miller jean also available.

The University of Michigan will proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" after initially canceling it. The cancellation followed a petition signed by over 200 students who argued the movie negatively depicted the Middle East. After a backlash and a counter-petition, the university's Vice President for Student Life reversed the decision, stating the cancellation was a mistake and inconsistent with the university's commitment to freedom of expression. The film will be shown, with an alternative screening of "Paddington" offered for students who prefer not to attend.

Two French male tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly set a quokka alight on Rottnest Island on April 3 using an aerosol spray and a lighter. The quokka survived but was singed. The men were charged with animal cruelty, evicted from the island, and are scheduled to appear in court on April 17.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a dancer in New York nightspots during the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen films of herself performing. With help from filmmakers, a video of her old performances was compiled and shown to her at her nursing home, to her great delight.

The tradition of washing your own car is declining in Britain, with a third of men and three-quarters of women admitting they have never done it. Drivers are now more likely to use a hand car wash, and factors behind the decline include more Sunday activities like shopping and football, the rise of convenient hand car washes, and the increasing size of modern vehicles.

Martin Skrtel praised the impact Steven Gerrard has had on him since 2008, calling him one of the world's best players and thanking him for helping him settle at Liverpool. Gerrard is set to leave for LA Galaxy at the end of the season, with Skrtel stating that Liverpool will "never be the same" without him. However, Skrtel believes the club has players who can replace Gerrard if they are given help from the team.

At age 75, Jack Nicklaus hit his first hole-in-one at Augusta during the Par-3 Contest, acing the 130-yard fourth hole while playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was one of five aces on the day, which tied a record. Nicklaus is a six-time Masters winner and one of five men to complete the career Grand Slam.

Severe storms with reported tornadoes struck Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night. In Kansas, a tornado was spotted near Goddard and moved northeast, missing Wichita. In Missouri, a possible tornado caused wind damage and flooding in Potosi, and baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. An expert warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous, and more storms were expected in the Midwest and nearby regions on Thursday.

Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty to a second-degree manslaughter charge for fatally shooting Eric Harris. Bates claims the shooting was accidental, stating he mistook his gun for a Taser. Following the hearing, a judge granted Bates permission to vacation in the Bahamas, a decision the Harris family called a message of apathy. The family's lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to his donations and friendship with the sheriff, which the sheriff's office denies. Bates's lawyer has released training documents to prove he was properly trained. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against champion Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the fight, he unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach. McGregor claims he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time. Their fractious relationship was highlighted during a promotional tour in Dublin when McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was cheered by players after quickly drinking a beer at a function. The act drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners and a professor, who argued he was glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with alcohol. In his defence, Health Minister Sussan Ley stated there was nothing wrong with his actions. The passage also notes that while a former prime minister, Bob Hawke, was known for similar behaviour, public attitudes towards binge drinking have since changed.

Indiana's Scott County is experiencing a significant HIV outbreak, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases, primarily among intravenous drug users of the painkiller Opana. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a short-term needle exchange program, which has distributed over 5,000 clean syringes, but health officials expect case numbers to rise. Pence, who opposes needle exchanges, is reviewing whether to extend the program beyond its 30-day limit. A bill to allow similar programs in other high-risk counties has passed the House but its future is uncertain in the Senate. The current program also faces sustainability issues as it was not allocated dedicated funding.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a 50-question test on his favorite football club, stating he would not dump her as a result of her passing score. She scored 43.5 out of 50, or 87 percent, with the boyfriend marking her paper in red pen and providing critical feedback. The test included questions on player positions, match scores, and opinions on players. Saskia posted the exam on Twitter, where it garnered mixed reactions, with some calling the boyfriend a legend and others criticizing his behavior.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years. In exchange for his unpaid work, which helped bring down figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, he was promised U.S. citizenship. After retiring due to health issues, Toro has not received citizenship and now faces deportation. He fears for his life if returned to Colombia and remains in the U.S. illegally after the DEA refused to help with his status.

In India, a 14-year-old girl set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. The attack reportedly occurred when she left her house to relieve herself, and her family allegedly told her to remain silent. The girl is now in a Delhi hospital with 70 percent burns. The accused men have been arrested. The incident is presented within the context of heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the government's ban of a documentary about the 2012 Delhi gang rape of student Jyoti Singh, whose death led to widespread protests and death sentences for her attackers. The passage also notes recent incidents of vigilante justice against alleged rapists in the country.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal dreams of beating Manchester City in their upcoming derby at Old Trafford but will be without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, who he has ruled out as not fit enough to play. A win would help United secure a high league finish, potentially second or third, to avoid Champions League qualifying fixtures and exceed pre-season goals. Reflecting on a previous 1-0 loss to City, Van Gaal stressed the need to control aggression rather than seek revenge. He also praised the Manchester United fans and anticipates a great atmosphere for the game.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match at the Emirates Stadium to protest against high ticket prices. Organized by fan groups from both clubs, the demonstration was a response to the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal, with tickets for the game starting at £64. Fans displayed banners reading "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket," arguing that prices are extortionate and risk losing a generation of supporters.

A newborn baby, Star Reader, was diagnosed with the life-threatening liver condition biliary atresia after birth, when an initial operation to unblock her bile ducts failed. With neither parent a suitable match for a necessary liver transplant, the baby's maternal aunt and mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader, donated part of her liver. The operation was successful, and after spending six weeks in the hospital, Star has made a good recovery and returned home, where she will require lifelong anti-rejection medication.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian competed in an Audi Football Challenge. Paired in a head-to-head contest, Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, which involved shooting into a car boot and playing tennis over an Audi. Remy and Willian won the final long-range shooting challenge, during which Willian broke a car's wing mirror.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a December 2013 highway crash that killed a Vermont couple, Jason Timmons and Amanda Murphy, and their unborn baby. He drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100 mph into their SUV. At his sentencing, Dellinger contradicted prosecutors by stating he was not suicidal, despite reportedly telling investigators he was trying to kill himself. His attorneys attributed his actions to Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and multiple sclerosis. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault and faces a potential prison sentence of 12 to 24 years.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul. Spears was convicted of poisoning him with a lethal amount of salt through his feeding tube. Prosecutors argued she made her son ill for attention, describing his life as "short and tormented," while her defense lawyer claimed she was a loving mother who is innocent and plans to appeal. The judge noted that Spears suffers from a mental illness but called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty." The boy's father, Chris Hill, reacted on Facebook, expressing his hope that she would die in prison.

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia a month later than expected after scientists modified it to include protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket. The change was prompted by a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States, as the previous vaccine was not a good match for these strains. Free government-funded flu shots will be available for high-risk groups from April 20, but experts recommend everyone get vaccinated to protect themselves and vulnerable people around them.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are on the defensive during the 150th anniversary of his assassination, facing an unflattering critique in National Geographic and looming state budget cuts. A historian in the magazine described the tomb's interior as a "disappointment" with "all the historical character of an office lobby." Concurrently, Illinois's financial crisis has prompted a proposal to eliminate the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, which has already experienced reduced hours and staffing due to funding cuts. In response, the state agency defends the site, highlighting over $2.5 million in recent renovations that have left it in "excellent physical condition," and noting that some visitors find the site impressive.

The passage observes that 1990s and noughties fashion trends are re-emerging, prompting a look at styles the author feels should have been left in the past. It lists nine specific "worst offenders," such as bucket hats, camouflage print, Ugg boots, and Juicy Couture tracksuits. For each trend, the article provides a "then" example of a celebrity from the original era and a "now" example of a modern celebrity reviving the look.

The passage summarizes a week of trending stories, highlighting four rainbows over New York, China's ban on exotic dancers at wakes, and an agitated interview with Robert Downey Jr. It also covers the #KylieJennerChallenge, a 102-year-old seeing old films of herself, a controversial prom-posal, casting news for 'Beauty and the Beast' and 'Black Mass', a 'Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' pregnancy announcement, and a military dad photobombing his son.

Serena Williams secured her 700th career victory at the Miami Open by defeating Sabine Lisicki in the quarter-finals. This milestone was celebrated with a large cake, similar to a presentation for Andy Murray's 500th win. Williams will now play Simona Halep in the semi-finals, after Halep beat Sloane Stephens. A potential match against her sister Venus will not occur, as Venus lost to Carla Suarez Navarro.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights activist and cafe owner, was shot and killed by gunmen at point-blank range outside her cafe in Karachi. The killing is believed to be linked to her advocacy for free speech, as she had just hosted a controversial discussion on the Baluchistan region, a topic that had been shut down at a university. Mahmud was a prominent national figure for progressive values, tolerance, and humanism, providing a rare space for open dialogue in a country where such expression is dangerous.

Approximately 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), who are mostly Hindu and fled to Indian Kashmir during the Partition 70 years ago, are treated as second-class citizens. They are denied the right to own property, vote in state elections, work for the state government, or attend state-run colleges, leading to three generations living in poverty. The state's rulers have historically withheld these rights to avoid upsetting the demographic balance of India's only Muslim-majority state. However, the community now has hope for change after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party (BJP) won a share of power in the state government and pledged to normalize the refugees' status.

Chelsea has made a £4 million offer for FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, a move confirmed by the Japanese club's president. The 22-year-old is still considering the transfer, stating he wants to join a club where he can play and develop, while Chelsea's plan is to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem. Muto's former manager, Ranko Popovic, has praised him as an intelligent, fast, and confident player who could succeed at Chelsea. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged that commercial interests are a factor in transfers but maintained that the club only signs good players or prospects.

The passage argues that England's rugby policy of not selecting overseas-based players is outdated and should be changed, especially after Australia recently dropped its own similar rule. It highlights English players like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon who have improved while playing in France, suggesting they should be eligible for selection. The author contends that to win the home World Cup, England must pick its strongest possible team, regardless of club location, and notes that other nations like South Africa and Wales continue to select their top players from overseas clubs.

Open Garden developed the FireChat app, which enables off-the-grid chatting by creating a wireless mesh network between phones using Bluetooth or Wi-Fi, without needing an internet or mobile signal. To overcome the network's range limit of about 200ft, Open Garden created Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster. Greenstone stores up to 1,000 messages and relays them to other FireChat users within its 20ft range, extending the network. FireChat, which has been downloaded over five million times, allows for secure and anonymous messaging and is useful in areas without connectivity. Greenstone is still under development and intended for use in situations like crowded events or emergencies where resilient communication is needed.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle is working to destigmatize the word 'fat' by embracing it as a positive, honest self-descriptor. In a TED talk, she explained that society often wrongly uses 'fat' as a synonym for 'ugly', contributing to size discrimination and negative body image among young girls. She uses her burlesque performances to expose audiences to body diversity, citing studies that show increased exposure leads to greater acceptance. Bustle finds her work personally empowering and has received a largely positive response to her TED talk online.

Arsenal winger Theo Walcott, who has frequently been on the bench this season, participated in a photoshoot with six teammates and a runway model for Lanvin, the club's official tailor. The team will be dressed by Lanvin for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa.

A collection of 417 props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker's Cinovation Studio will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on Propstore.com. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions spanning Baker's 30-year career. Fans can bid on pieces from films like *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, and *Gremlins 2*, with some individual items, like the Alien Edgar Bug from *Men in Black*, expected to fetch over $40,000. The no-reserve auction offers the public a chance to own these creations for the first time.

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell died after falling from a 164ft drop in the French Alps during a family ski holiday. He became separated from his mother and sister and left the marked piste, entering woodland in an apparent attempt to walk back to the resort which he could see. Police located his body by following his footprints in the snow. His family described him as a daring, outgoing, and determined boy and expressed their devastation, while his school community in Wales is also grieving.

Laura Scurr, a schoolgirl from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 after being bullied about her weight and feeling pressured to be a "size zero." She began hiding food and surviving on as little as one piece of fruit or 100 calories a day. Her body began to shut down, leading her to collapse and require a week on a heart monitor in the hospital. Following her discharge, Laura received support from eating disorder services, recovered, and has now reached the semi-finals of the Miss Teen GB competition, which promotes positive body image.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit at Anfield, the first offering from new supplier New Balance, who signed a record £300 million deal. The event was overshadowed by Raheem Sterling's contract situation, as he had recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and expressed interest in joining Arsenal. Liverpool fans at the launch made it clear they expect him to stay at the club. Players also commented on the importance of the fans and the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa. The new kit features a gingham design, all-white branding, and a tribute to the Hillsborough victims.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky. Created as part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES), the map was made using data from a telescope in Chile to measure the gravitational distortion of 130 million galaxies. This is the first in a series of maps with the goal of charting 12.5% of the sky by 2018 to create a 3D view. The project aims to study galaxy formation, test cosmological theories, and understand the nature of dark energy.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven forward Memphis Depay. Manager Louis van Gaal, who previously coached Depay for the Dutch national team, is keen to sign him. PSV confirmed the approach and noted interest from other major clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain, with the transfer fee expected to be higher than a previous £15 million offer from Tottenham. Depay has scored 20 league goals this season to help PSV win the Dutch championship and is a highly-rated, pacy attacker who has been compared to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea took a commanding 3-1 lead over Manchester City in the first leg of their tie in Manchester. Tammy Abraham gave the visitors a first-half lead with two goals, both volleys. Manchester City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalized, but Abraham completed his double with an acrobatic finish. A late goal from Dominic Solanke secured Chelsea's victory.

Presidential candidate Marco Rubio claims people are born with a sexual preference, but he does not believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right. He maintains that state legislatures, not courts, should define marriage as between one man and one woman. Despite this political stance, Rubio personally stated he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, explaining he would respect their decision out of love.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, quit their restaurant jobs to embark on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. In their first year, they have cycled almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They maintain a budget of less than three euros per person daily by relying on free accommodation like camping and hosting websites, and eating a diet of basic staples, foraged, and donated food. Their route, starting from London, has taken them through Western and Eastern Europe, the Balkans, and Turkey, with their latest destination being Armenia. They plan to continue into Asia, across the Pacific, and down the length of the Americas over the coming years.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 is suing their photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, claiming a photo booth rented from him printed pictures with a racial slur. The couple discovered the photos months after the event when the bride's sister informed them, having waited to avoid upsetting the couple on their wedding day. The couple's attorney alleges that when confronted, James Evans did not apologize and told them to "sue me." Evans denies the allegations, stating there is no evidence linking his company to the photos. The couple, whose main goal is an apology, has a mediation scheduled with a trial to follow in July if an agreement is not reached.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovering from a concussion and is unsure when he will return. After feeling unwell following a game against France, he withdrew from a Harlequins match. Brown, who was previously knocked out against Italy, is determined to avoid a long-term absence like other players such as Johnny Sexton and George North. He credits World Rugby online modules for increasing his awareness of concussion symptoms, which now leads him to advise teammates against playing through potential head injuries.

Research indicates a decline in the frequency of sex among couples since the emergence of the internet. A typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. A leading expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter, suggests that smartphone and internet use may be to blame. He theorizes that constant connectivity erodes the boundaries between work and private life, leaving less "quiet time" for couples. As a result, with competing demands on their time, sex becomes a lower priority, and people may be too connected to the outside world by bedtime to focus on their partner.

Tibetan Mastiffs in China have fallen from being status symbols once sold for up to £1.2 million to being so unpopular they are sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather. The breed's collapse is blamed on an anti-corruption crackdown that ended their use as gifts for officials, bans on large dogs in cities, and their unsuitability for urban life. A market glut of poor-quality dogs, resulting from profit-driven cross-breeding, also contributed to the decline. Animal-welfare workers have rescued dogs being transported in cruel conditions, and it is feared hundreds are meeting a similar fate.

A survey of 600 women in Paris found that every woman has been a victim of sexual harassment on public transport, with half experiencing it before turning 18. The harassment, which ranges from insults to rape, causes fear and forces women to alter their daily lives, thereby excluding them from public spaces. Compiled by the High Council for Gender Equality, the poll has led to calls for a campaign and education aimed at women, aggressors, and witnesses, as attackers are believed to act with total impunity.

The insurance company Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to find solutions for common daily problems. Following a survey of top "everyday emergencies," design groups created three shortlisted prototype products: 'Snooze', an alarm clock that silences phone notifications; 'Forget Me Lock', a key device that shows if your door is locked; and 'Nipper', a small phone charger that uses a household battery. The public can vote for their favorite on Twitter by retweeting, and the winning product will be funded into production through a Kickstarter campaign.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is facing a Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating over £500,000 of public funds to a charity she directs. The Chief Constable, Sue Sim, is also a director of the charity, Victims First Northumbria. Critics have described the action as inappropriate and a conflict of interest. Baird has defended her decision, stating that all procedures were followed.

Three people were imprisoned and two await sentencing for assaulting 53-year-old Greg Valecce. Ringleader Cory Campbell, believing Valecce injured his cat and stole from him, led a group that beat Valecce, tied him to a chair in a Philadelphia basement for 42 hours, and forcibly tattooed him with offensive images, including "RIP Pebbles," swastikas, and racial slurs. Campbell and an accomplice, Carl Halin, were each sentenced to 20 years in prison, while another accomplice, Sandra Ng, received a 23-month sentence. Two other defendants are awaiting sentencing and trial.

Manchester United, under manager Louis van Gaal, has made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay. Van Gaal, who managed Depay at the 2014 World Cup, is keen to sign the Dutch international. Depay has had a prolific season, scoring 20 league goals as PSV won the Eredivisie. His value has increased beyond a previous £15 million offer from Tottenham, and he is also attracting interest from other major European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain.

Chelsea took a commanding 3-1 lead against Manchester City's young side in Manchester. Tammy Abraham scored twice for Chelsea in the first half, after Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had levelled the game for City, and Dominic Solanke added a late third goal to seal the win.

Presidential candidate Marco Rubio stated that while he believes people are born with their sexual preference, he maintains the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He does not believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and thinks state legislatures, not courts, should regulate marriage. Despite his personal disagreement, Rubio said he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cares about.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde quit their restaurant jobs to cycle around the world with no set plans. In almost one year, they have traveled nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, from London to their current location in Armenia. The couple lives on less than three euros each per day by using free accommodation, such as camping and hosting websites, and eating a simple diet of staples, gifted meals, and foraged food. They plan to continue their journey into Asia, across the Pacific, and through the Americas for the next several years.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from a concussion, having withdrawn from a club match and the England-Ireland game after experiencing headaches. He is determined not to rush his return to avoid a long-term absence, citing the cases of other players like Johnny Sexton and George North. Brown credits his increased awareness of concussion symptoms and their dangers to World Rugby online modules, which now lead him to urge teammates not to play through symptoms.

A leading expert has suggested that smartphone use may be to blame for a decline in how often couples have sex, with the frequency for a typical heterosexual couple dropping from five times a month in 1990 to three times currently. The decline is attributed to technology blurring the boundaries between public and private life, leaving people constantly connected and busy, which reduces private time and causes sex to become a lower priority.

Once highly sought-after status symbols in China selling for up to £1.2 million, the market for Tibetan Mastiffs has collapsed. The breed's dramatic fall in popularity is attributed to the government's anti-corruption drive, which curtailed their use as gifts to officials, city bans on large dogs over 50kg, and over-breeding which created a glut of low-quality animals. Consequently, many dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat and leather, with animal welfare groups rescuing dogs found in horrific conditions during transport.

Leeds-based company Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to create products that solve common "everyday emergencies" identified in a survey. Three prototypes were shortlisted: 'Snooze', an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to help with sleep; 'Forget Me Lock', a device for a key that shows red for locked and green for unlocked; and 'Nipper', a small phone charger that uses a household battery. The public can vote for their favorite on Twitter, and the winner will be developed following a Kickstarter campaign.

The 2009 convention had over 512 guests and performers, including notables such as Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.

The 2009 convention had over 6000 guests and musical performers, including notables like Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
